resumen:
Job creation and inflation are key to rate cuts.

Federal Reserve officials are meeting this week.

The Trump administration has reduced economy-threatening tariffs to more manageable levels, but the U.S. still hasn't reached trade deals with most other countries.

An actual war between Israel and Iran threatens to raise oil prices.

Economists at Oxford Economics wrote that "The economy has slowed and is vulnerable to anything else going wrong, including a sudden and persistent increase in oil prices".

Fed officials have signaled ahead of their two-day meeting this week that they are likely to leave interest rates unchanged.

Sam Bullard, senior economist at Wells Fargo, said "Bottom line, the bar that leads to Fed rate action remains high".

The economy has clearly suffered a blow from the trade wars.

The most visible sign was a contraction in gross domestic product in the first quarter, for the first time in three years.

Consumers bought lots of cars in March and April to beat the tariffs, and drove up sales to a four-year high.

Vehicle sales sank 10% in May as tariffs kicked in.

The stop-and-start trade wars have effectively have created a stop-and-go economy.

The Fed will release the updated projections they publish four times a year at the June meeting.

In March, the Fed projected GDP growth would slow to 1.7% in 2025 from just under 3% in both 2024 and 2023.

A new poll of top Wall Street DJIA SPX economists lowered its 2025 GDP forecast to 1.3% from close to 2% before the trade wars began in March.

The Fed a few months ago saw the jobless rate rising to 4.4% by the end of 2025 from the current 4.2% level.

Inflation has stayed low since the trade wars erupted.

The rate of inflation using the Fed's preferred personal consumption expenditures price index stood at 2.2% in May, not far from the Fed's 2% long-run goal.

Fed officials predicted in March that inflation would rise to 2.7% by year-end.

Wall Street is betting on two rate cuts for this year.

title: Canada U-turns on supply management policy protection
content: A bill that would make Canada’s supply management policy non-negotiable in trade talks is quickly progressing through parliament ...
resumen: A bill, C-202, is progressing through parliament to make Canada’s supply management policy non-negotiable in trade talks. The bill would amend Canada’s foreign affairs, trade and development act to prevent ministers from negotiating away the system’s import controls, specifically raising tariff rate quotas for dairy products, poultry or eggs, or lowering tariffs on foreign goods that exceed import quotas. The bill was tabled by the leader of Bloc Québécois and was supported unanimously by all MPs in the House of Commons. The bill is now up for a third reading in the Senate. Pierre J. Dalphond, senator from Quebec, urged the Senate to adopt Bill C-202 in a timely way. Canada’s supply management system, set up in the 1970s, regulates domestic production of dairy, eggs, and poultry to provide a stable supply and fair farm income by limiting imports through tariff rate quotas (TRQs). For dairy, tariff rates vary between 200% and more than 300%; for poultry, rates can reach 289% and between 150% and 164% for eggs. Bill C-202 is designed to bolster the third pillar by preventing concessions on the import of dairy, poultry and eggs during trade negotiations. It is identical to Bill C-282, which stalled in the Senate but received backing from the House, with 262 of the 313 MPs voting in favor, including leaders of the Liberal Party of Canada, the Conservative Party of Canada, the New Democratic Party and the Green Party. Canada’s supply management policy is crucial for Quebec’s ag economy, which generates 36% of farm revenue from supply management receipts. Quebec is also the largest dairy-producer in the country, with more than 4,400 of the nation’s 9000+ dairy farms based there. Dairy Farmers of Canada claim that up to 18% of some dairy product quotas are open to external markets. The US finds that Canada slaps US imports above quota levels with ‘prohibitively high tariffs’. Under the terms of the 2020 USMCA, US dairy producers received improved market access opportunities through new TRQs. Dairy contributes CA$28bn (US$20.6bn) to Canada’s GDP and generates CA$9bn (US$6.64bn) in tax revenue annually. It’s the second largest market for US dairy exports with 221,883 metric tons of product at a value of US$1.14bn shipped across the border in 2024. Over the past decade, US dairy exports to Canada have grown 82%, according to USDA data.

title: Arranca en Canadá reunión del G7
content: En agenda encuentro de la presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, con sus homólogos de Estados Unidos y Canadá, Donald Trump y Mark Carney.
resumen:
Arranca en Canadá la reunión del G7.
En la agenda, encuentro de la presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, con sus homólogos de Estados Unidos y Canadá, Donald Trump y Mark Carney.
La reunión de los mandatarios del G7 inició el lunes al rededor del mediodía, integrado por Alemania, Canadá, Francia, Italia, Japón, Reino Unido y Estados Unidos.
Brasil, México y Ucrania asisten como invitados al encuentro anual en el que también la Unión Europea lleva representación.
Otros mandatarios invitados a la región boscosa de Kananaskis, Alberta, son los de Australia, Corea del Sur, Emiratos Árabes Unidos, India y Sudáfrica.
Está contemplado que la presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum se reúna el martes con el mandatario de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump; con el primer ministro canadiense Mark Carney; con el premier de la India Narendra Modi; y así como con Úrsula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisión Europea y con António Costa, presidente del Consejo Europeo; mientras que durante este lunes se tiene previsto una reunión con el sector privado canadiense.
La agenda de Trump no descarta para hoy un primer encuentro con Sheimbaum, aunque diversas fuentes ya han confirmado que sería hasta el martes que formalmente sostengan la cita.
La reunión de Sheimbaum será alrededor de las 4 o 5 pm (tiempo local) con el Consejo Empresarial de Canadá, encabezado por Goldy Hyder, donde hablaran sobre posibles inversiones en México así como para fortalecer la relación entre sectores público y privado de ambos países.
Los temas más importante a desarrollarse con Trump serán tratados en una hora de conversaciones que iniciaría a la 15:40 de la tarde del martes, destacando la relación comercial, especialmente en el contexto del T-MEC, aranceles; migración sobre todo por las redadas y la persecución contra mexicanos migrantes; así como seguridad y narcotráfico, principalmente de fentanilo.
Para la reunión con Carney, se contempla que el T-MEC, cómo mantenerlo y fortalecerlo, será el tema principal sin dejar de lado las relaciones comerciales entre ambos países para explorar oportunidades de inversión y cooperación económica entre México y Canadá, incluyendo la defensa conjunta del comercio binacional frente a las políticas arancelarias de Trump.

title: Wall Street’s projected tariff winner? Goodyear Tire

resumen: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co. has become a stock market darling as analysts and investors eye it as a potential tariff winner. Only 12 percent of the company’s supply for the U.S. is sourced outside of the USMCA, and its Canadian and Mexican factories are fully compliant, according to a May 8 financial results call. The company estimated a $300 million total tariff impact and predicted that competitors could face three to four times that amount. Mark Stewart, Goodyear CEO, said on the May call, “We feel we’re in a really favorable, strong position.” Goodyear is more than halfway through its two-year transformation plan ending in December. The company announced the sale of its Dunlop brand on May 7. It announced the sale of the majority of its chemical business for $650 million on May 22. Goodyear is increasing its production capacity by 10 million premium tires in 2025 and 2026. The value of automotive tire and tube imports grew by $102 million from March 2024 to March 2025. Goodyear’s rise, including a 31 percent increase in its stock price since the beginning of 2025, underscores the tariffs’ power. Firms such as BNP Paribas raising ratings for Goodyear and calling the tire maker a “true tariff winner.” About 80 percent of the company’s exposure is aftermarket, while about 20 percent of business goes to automakers. Goodyear sells about 60 million tires in the U.S. each year. Goodyear predicts it will incur tariffs on raw materials and commercial tires. The company adjusted its working capital for the first quarter to reflect the tariffs.

title: Tariff turmoil as trade tensions intensify
content: As the U.S. intensifies its tariff measures — raising duties on steel and aluminium imports and targeting strategic sectors — Mexico finds itself at a critical juncture.
resumen:
The U.S. is intensifying its tariff measures, raising duties on steel and aluminum imports and targeting strategic sectors, which is causing concern in Mexico. Sectoral tariffs and foreign investment anxieties are prompting negotiations, industry lobbying, and contingency planning, especially within the automotive sector.

Umberto Torresan, senior business analyst for ICIS in the U.S., stated that Mexico has a 10 percent tariff in general, and there are some sectoral tariffs that supersede the U.S.-Mexico-Canada (USMCA) Agreement, particularly affecting the automotive sector. The US administration started a new 50 percent tariff on steel and aluminum on June 4, which increases costs.

During the first Trump administration, Ford and Fiat Chrysler moved production facilities from Mexico to Michigan in the U.S. Nissan, which produces about 300,000 vehicles in Mexico, said it might move to the US if there's no solution to the tariffs.

Foreign direct investment in Mexico decreased by 21 percent during the first quarter due to concerns about tariffs and USMCA compliance. The Mexican government is working on compliance problems, and industries are lobbying with their U.S. counterparts.

The USMCA Agreement expires next year, and the Mexican government wants an early review before September. Ciudad Juárez lost 40 percent of exports in the past month because of tariffs.

The automotive and electronics industries are most affected by the steel tariffs. The aerospace industry might also be hit.

Mexico has protection under the USMCA, but there are challenges compared to countries in Asia or South America. Rising labor costs in Mexico stem from the minimum wage requirement of $16 an hour for North American products. The USMCA is supposed to shut down in 2036.

Mexican PU producers can differentiate suppliers, create more redundancy in the supply network, and consider options like creative nearshoring, pre-buying, product configuration adjustments, and applying for the First Sale Rule. Companies can use digital assets to simulate tariff scenarios. An automotive company in Mexico is thinking of including clauses on tariffs in their long-term contracts.

title: Trump attends G7 summit amid escalating trade tensions and global conflicts
content: The annual meeting of the Group of 7 nations includes Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States.
resumen:
President Donald Trump is attending the G7 summit in Kananaskis, Alberta on Monday, June 16, 2025. The summit is hosted by Canada and includes Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, and the United States. The meeting focuses on finding common ground on international challenges.

The wars in Ukraine and Gaza are ongoing, the conflict between Israel and Iran over Tehran's nuclear program is escalating, and Trump's tariffs are affecting several nations.

Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney opened the summit, stating the world is "more divided and dangerous." He predicted "frank discussions" over the two-day summit.

Trump addressed trade agreements, stating, "We have our trade deals. All we have to do is send a letter, ‘This is what you’re going to have to pay.'"

On Monday morning, Carney met with Trump to discuss the trade standoff. Trump said a trade deal is achievable, but they approach it differently. The United States has a 25% tariff on goods from Canada and a 10% tariff on Canadian energy. Canada imposed its own tariffs on more than $100 billion of American goods in response. Canada’s 25% counter tariffs on auto imports from the U.S. took effect in April for items that do not comply with the 2020 USMCA pact.

Trump continues to push the idea of Canada becoming the 51st state. In May, Carney met with Trump at the White House and protected Canada's sovereignty.

British Prime Minister Keir Starmer will hold a one-on-one meeting with President Trump about finalizing the U.K.-U.S. trade deal.

French President Emmanuel Macron held talks with Trump before the summit, discussing tariffs, the situation in the Near and Middle East, and the situation in Ukraine. Trump was also expected to meet with German Chancellor Friedrich Merz.

The four European G7 leaders held an informal meeting Sunday night, without Trump, discussing the conflict between Iran and Israel.

Trump is also expected to have bilateral meetings with Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

In 2018, Trump rejected a joint communique reached by world leaders over trade. He called then-Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau "very dishonest and weak."

The German, U.K., Japanese, and Italian governments believe a friendly relationship with Trump can reduce outbursts.

title: WATCH: Trump says U.S., Canada have 'different concepts' for trade deal
content: President Donald Trump said Monday that he and Canada Prime Minister Mark Carney have different concepts for trade between the two neighboring countries but hope to ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump said Monday that he and Canada Prime Minister Mark Carney have different concepts for trade between the two neighboring countries but hope to reach an agreement soon. Trump met with Carney at the G7 Summit in Kananaskis, in the Canadian Rockies. Trump dominated the brief news conference, and Carney essentially let Trump lead the conversation with reporters ahead of the meeting.

Trump said they had different concepts for what a trade deal would look like. "It's not so much holding up, I think we have different concepts, I have a tariff concept, Mark has a different concept, which is something that some people like, but we're going to see if we can get to the bottom of it today." Trump continued: "I'm a tariff person, I've always been a tariff person. It's simple. It's easy. It's precise and it just goes very quickly. And I think Mark has a more complex idea, but also very good, so we're going to look at both and we're going to come out with something hopefully."

Trump said a deal was "achievable" quickly, but didn't give a more precise timeline. Shortly after taking office in January, Trump hit Canada and Mexico with 25% tariffs for allowing fentanyl and migrants to cross their borders into the U.S. Trump later applied those 25% tariffs only to goods that fall outside the free-trade agreement between the three nations, called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement. Trump put a 10% tariff on non-USMCA compliant potash and energy products. A 50% tariff on aluminum and steel imports from all countries into the U.S. has been in effect since June 4. Trump also put a 25% tariff on all cars and trucks not built in the U.S.

The tariffs have frustrated Canadian leaders and residents. Tensions between the two neighboring countries have been high. Trump has repeatedly suggested that Canada join the U.S. as its 51st state. He previously called former Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau "governor" regularly. Economists, businesses and some publicly traded companies have warned that tariffs could raise prices on a wide range of consumer products. Trump has said he wants to use tariffs to restore manufacturing jobs lost to lower-wage countries in decades past, shift the tax burden away from U.S. families, and pay down the national debt. A tariff is a tax on imported goods paid by the person or company that imports the goods. The importer can absorb the cost of the tariffs or try to pass the cost on to consumers through higher prices.

title: Bosch stays steady amid tariffs, but exec worries about smaller auto suppliers' survival
content: That’s the takeaway from Paul Thomas, president of Bosch North America, who said Monday that the company isn’t panicking over global trade disruptions but is keeping a watchful eye on sub-tier ...
resumen:
Bosch is keeping operations stable through big headwinds from tariffs to rare earth mineral shortages, but the manufacturing behemoth is worried about sub-tier suppliers with fewer resources.

Paul Thomas, president of Bosch North America, said Monday that the company isn’t panicking over global trade disruptions but is keeping a watchful eye on sub-tier suppliers with less financial runway than Bosch, the world’s largest automotive supplier.

Thomas made the comments during a panel discussion ahead of the annual Automotive News Golf Classic at Saint John’s Resort in Plymouth.

Thomas was joined by Collin Shaw, president of MEMA Original Equipment Suppliers.

Trump implemented a 25% tariff on vehicles built outside the U.S. starting April 3, with some auto parts including engines, transmissions, and powertrain and electrical components also subject to the import duty. Additionally, parts that are not USMCA-compliant are subject to tariffs, and the administration doubled steel and aluminum tariffs to 50% effective June 4.

Bosch is forecasting stable production for the rest of the year.

title: US-China trade war reshapes global flows: India sees import surge, export rise
content: The dramatic decline in China’s shipments to the U.S. is being partially offset by increased exports to other markets, including the EU (up 12% to $49.5 billion), ASEAN (up 15% to $58.4 billion), and ...
resumen:
The U.S.-China trade war has significantly altered global trade flows, with India experiencing a surge in imports, particularly in electronics and machinery from China, and an increase in exports to the U.S.

Latest trade figures from China Customs (June 10) and India’s Commerce Ministry (June 16) reveal how the U.S.-China trade war is reshaping global trade flows.

May 2025 data indicates a sharp drop in China’s exports to the U.S. and a noticeable redirection of trade to markets like India, the EU, and ASEAN, according to the Delhi-based think tank Global Trade Research Initiative (GTRI).

China’s overall exports grew modestly by 4.6%, from $302.1 billion in May 2024 to $316.2 billion in May 2025, while its exports to the United States plummeted by 34.5%, from $44.0 billion to just $28.8 billion over the same period.

The dramatic decline in China's shipments to the U.S. is being partially offset by increased exports to other markets, including the EU (up 12% to $49.5 billion), ASEAN (up 15% to $58.4 billion), and notably, India (up 12.4% to $11.13 billion).

India's overall merchandise imports dipped slightly by 1.8% year-on-year, from $61.7 billion in May 2024 to $60.6 billion in May 2025.

Stripping out petroleum, gold, and diamonds, India's imports actually rose by 12%, from $36.8 billion to $41.2 billion.

India's net customs revenue from IGST rose by 72.9%, increasing from ₹24,510 crore in May 2024 to ₹42,370 crore in May 2025.

Two categories with high import growth stood out: electronics (up 27.5% to $9.1 billion) and machinery and computers (up 22% to $5 billion).

India's combined imports from China and Hong Kong surged by 22.4%, from $9.8 billion to $12 billion.

India's exports to the United States jumped 17.3% to $8.8 billion.

India's merchandise exports dipped marginally to $38.73 billion during May 2025 as compared to $39.59 billion in May last year.

The decline was cushioned by a 54.1% increase in electronic goods exports, $4.57 billion in May 2025 as compared to $2.97 billion in May 2024.

title: Is the US undermining ‘Made in America’ apparel manufacturing?
content: When it comes to reshoring garment manufacturing, the Trump administration’s tariffs are at odds with its immigration crackdown.
resumen: The Trump administration's tariffs aimed at reshoring apparel manufacturing are at odds with its immigration crackdowns. Executives from department stores and apparel retailers have described how new tariff policies have them scrambling to acquire goods under the lowest possible import duties, negotiating with factories to share the impact and ultimately sourcing fewer goods from China. Few are working to acquire more clothing made in America. Textile manufacturing has largely moved overseas, with what's left of the industry in the U.S. centered in Los Angeles. Textile factories represent the city’s largest manufacturing sector, employing more than 45,000 workers, mostly from Latin America and Asia. According to a recent Garment Worker Center survey of 140 respondents, more than 60% are undocumented and just 14% documented. Garment workers were caught up in the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement raids that have sparked protests in Los Angeles. At least 20 workers were detained at two apparel companies. Immigrants have been key to apparel manufacturing because cutting, sewing and finishing requires hand labor. The pay is very low, but the work lends itself to immigrants. Trump seemed to acknowledge that difficulty, at least for food production and hospitality, and hinted at policy adjustments for those industries. There is now a pause on raids at farms and hospitality businesses, but it’s unclear how that affects garment factories. The low wages and working conditions of U.S. garment manufacturing haven’t changed much over the years. Many immigrants stick with the work in hopes of providing opportunity for their families. The Garment Worker Center called for “smart tariffs tied to labor rights violations, paired with real protections for workers here and abroad,” but warned that “tariffs alone will not support domestic industries.” The U.S. has the workforce needed for a thriving apparel industry. The Garment Worker Center said that “the assault on our immigrant labor force ... only makes life harder for workers and staying in business that much more difficult for thousands of factories, manufacturers, and brands.” Sustaining and growing the industry here would take investment. Returning apparel manufacturing to the U.S. isn’t a priority of the administration or its tariff policy. Trump stated, “I'm not looking to make T-shirts, to be honest. I'm not looking to make socks. We can do that very well at other locations.” Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said at an April press conference, “We don't need to necessarily have a booming textile industry.”

title: Massachusetts Governor Hosts New England-Canada Summit in Boston to Tackle Trump Tariff Challenges
content: Gov. Healey hosted a summit with New England governors and Canadian officials to discuss the impact of Trump-era tariffs.
resumen: La gobernadora de Massachusetts, Maura Healey, se reunió con otros gobernadores de Nueva Inglaterra y funcionarios canadienses en Boston para discutir los efectos económicos de los aranceles introducidos durante la administración Trump. La cumbre se centró en apoyar a las empresas locales y explorar la cooperación en energía, comercio, turismo y manufactura. Los gobernadores Kelly Ayotte de New Hampshire y Ned Lamont de Connecticut no asistieron, pero enviaron representantes. No se dio ninguna razón específica para la ausencia de la gobernadora Ayotte. Los aranceles de la era Trump han creado incertidumbre económica en Massachusetts, afectando la planificación empresarial, el turismo y la presupuestación estatal. Se ha informado de una disminución del turismo transfronterizo, especialmente en estados como Maine. La gobernadora Healey enfatizó la importancia de mantener fuertes lazos con las provincias canadienses, incluso en medio de tensiones a nivel federal. Además, el presupuesto suplementario de Massachusetts incluye más de $500 millones en ayuda para hospitales y atención domiciliaria para ancianos. Con el año fiscal que termina pronto, los legisladores se están preparando para un posible presupuesto provisional para evitar interrupciones después del 1 de julio. title: The Fed is once again overlooking the disinflation caused by Trump’s tariffs and policies
content: Bloomberg notes that the Israeli-Iran war will likely affect the US bond market. “The yield on 10-year US bonds rose three basis points to 4.43% on Monday, underperforming German peers. Traders pared ...
resumen:
The Fed is overlooking the disinflation caused by Trump’s tariffs and policies.

The coming weeks are loaded with explosives. Today there is a Treasury auction of 20-years. Also today there is Italy CPI, the Empire State index, and Canadian housing starts. Tuesday brings the Bank of Japan decision (a hold expected), ZEW and US retail sales. Then it’s the Fed policy meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday where it might suggest a July (or Sept) rate cut. Wednesday brings UK CPI, eurozone CPI and TICs. Thursday it’s the Bank of England and Friday, UK retail sales. The Swiss National Bank also meets on Thursday. Then there is “triple witching” on June 20th when stock options, stock index futures, and stock index options all expire. Then there is the July 4 holiday that delivers a three-day weekend in all US markets, and right after that, the July 9 end of the pause on the 50% tariff on the EU.

The Israeli-Iran war will likely affect the US bond market. The yield on 10-year US bonds rose three basis points to 4.43% on Monday, underperforming German peers. Traders pared bets on interest-rate cuts from the Federal Reserve, pricing 46 basis points by the end of the year, compared to 49 basis points on Friday. US Treasuries are down since tensions between Israel and Iran turned into a direct conflict on Friday. Iran’s direct strikes in April 2024 and another flare-up between the two nations in October had also pushed up US yields rapidly and kept them elevated over a 30-day period, Bloomberg analysis showed.

More and more analysts and reporters are calling the Fed “behind the curve”. The Labor Department’s May survey of households found 700,000 fewer people with jobs than in April. The prime interest rate is 7.5%, too high for most businesses. Credit-card interest rates are above 20%, a record high. The mortgage rate is prohibitive, driving up housing costs and rents. Monthly mortgage payments are at a record high, and builder confidence is down.

The Fed is failing to see the disinflationary movement that the tariff regime and other Trump policies are generating. David Malpass says Trump is doing all the right thing.

The known unknown is whether the Israel-Iran conflict harms the oil market. The Strait of Hormuz carries about 20% of the world’s oil. Reuters notes that oil is still down some 8% y/y.

Markets are not willing to let war in the Middle East upset their apple carts as long as the US stays out of it directly. This is a vote of no-confidence in the US as a safe-haven.

Of the many important developments this week, the SNB rate decision and comments, plus Trump at G7 in Canada are chosen. The Swiss franc is the premier safe haven currency and it could be headed for an interest rate of zero or negative.

As for Trump at G7, expect false claims of trade deals and bluster about how he is the most important person ever in the history of the world.

We can’t imagine what would drive the dollar up except the well-nigh impossibility of the Fed saying it’s thinking of raising rates.

There is a tax provision that would allow Trump to apply a tax of 5-20% on countries that he imagines are taxing US companies unfairly.

About 2,000 “No Kings” demonstrations took place while Trump has having his military parade—in all 50 states and Washington, DC.

title: Delegación de Estados Unidos busca “revertir” déficit comercial con Perú: ¿qué ofrecen al país?
content: EXCLUSIVO. Una delegación especial del Departamento de Agricultura de Estados Unidos estuvo de visita en Perú para fomentar nuevos acuerdos con empresas peruanas. Aseguran que existe un déficit comerc ...
resumen: Una delegación especial del Departamento de Agricultura de Estados Unidos (USDA) visitó Perú para fomentar nuevos acuerdos con empresas peruanas. El objetivo es revertir un déficit comercial de US$ 3.66 mil millones al cierre del 2024, ya que Perú exporta más a Estados Unidos (EE.UU.) de lo que este país le vende a la nación latinoamericana. El Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC) entre ambos países se firmó en 2009. Daniel Whitley, administrador del Servicio Agrícola Exterior (FAS) del USDA, estuvo de visita en Perú junto a 35 empresas, 17 asociaciones comerciales y funcionarios de 5 estados de su país. El comercio bilateral se ha triplicado entre 2009 y 2024. EE.UU. ha aumentado sus exportaciones agrícolas a Perú en un 57% en el mismo periodo. La delegación buscó conectarse con empresas peruanas en sectores como lácteos, carne de cerdo, snacks, panadería y confitería, vinos y licores, alimentos para perros y gatos, entre otros. Las 35 empresas agroindustriales de EE.UU. que visitaron el Perú también proveen productos como mariscos, soya, frutas frescas, quesos y legumbres. Visitaron los supermercados Wong y Tottus. Se sostuvieron reuniones con representantes del sector agroexportador peruano, quienes fueron acompañados también por el ministro de Agricultura y Riego (Midagri), Ángel Manero. La secretaria del USDA, Brooke Rollins, visitará Perú este año. El funcionario de la USDA reconoció que la nueva visión de su país sobre la política comercial puede generar resistencia entre el empresariado peruano, pero minimizó su posible impacto en el objetivo de la agencia gubernamental que representa. Estados Unidos y Perú comparten casi 200 años de relación bilateral. El objetivo actual de la USDA es reducir el déficit comercial negativo para EE.UU., sin impedir que nuevos productos peruanos ingresen al mercado estadounidense. El gobierno actual de EE.UU. ve al Perú como un socio clave, especialmente por sus frutas y hortalizas. EE.UU. ofrece al Perú: carnes de alta calidad, etanol, productos lácteos, snacks y alimentos envasados, frutas frescas y nueces, e ingredientes para la industria alimentaria y de bebidas.

title: Conflicto irano-israelí podría disparar inflación y precio global del petróleo
content: Conflicto irano-israelí podría disparar inflación y precio global del petróleo-. La escalada de tensiones en Oriente Medio con los ataques... Leer más ...
resumen: Tras recrudecerse las hostilidades a lo largo del fin de semana, hay temor a que un conflicto prolongado entre ambas potencias genere todavía más inestabilidad en la región. La escalada de tensiones en Oriente Medio con los ataques entre Israel e Irán ha sembrado de más incertidumbre a una economía global que ya se estaba viendo afectada por la crisis de aranceles desatada por Donald Trump y las crisis en Gaza, Ucrania. El precio del petróleo llegó a dispararse más del 13% en los mercados internacionales el viernes hasta superar los 78 dólares en el caso del barril de Brent. Se trata del mayor repunte diario de esta materia prima desde que se produjo la invasión rusa de Ucrania a comienzos de 2022. Su precio despidió finalmente la semana con un alza del 7% hasta los 74,23 dólares. La ofensiva israelí ha desatado el miedo a una guerra más amplia en una región clave para la producción mundial de petróleo. Un dron israelí atacó la planta de gas de Fajr Jam, que abastece al yacimiento de gas más grande del mundo, South Pars, el cual Irán comparte con Qatar. Debido al incendio, la extracción de 12 millones de metros cúbicos de gas se detuvo temporalmente hasta que las operaciones se restablecieron. Irán ostenta la segunda mayor reserva de gas natural en el mundo, al representar más del 17 % de los suministros mundiales, además de ser el tercer productor de este recurso después de los Estados Unidos y Rusia. Es el cuarto productor mundial de petróleo, y nuevos ataques contra sus instalaciones petroleras podrían elevar aún más los precios y provocar inflación en países fuera de la región. Según el Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI), la inflación en las economías avanzadas aumenta aproximadamente 0,4 puntos porcentuales por cada aumento del 10 % en los precios del petróleo. En Latinoamérica, se prevé que algunas naciones sufran el incremento de los precios de los combustibles, toda vez que importan petróleo para cubrir su demanda interna. Ese aumento, a su vez, puede desequilibrar la balanza comercial y empujar la inflación. Las preocupaciones de los expertos también están relacionadas con la posibilidad de que Irán bloquee el estrecho de Ormuz. Se trata de una de las vías marítimas más críticas del mundo, por la cual se movilizan casi 20 millones de barriles de petróleo diarios, aproximadamente una quinta parte del suministro mundial. El bloqueo podría provocar interrupciones en las cadenas de suministro. Los países europeos serán especialmente vulnerables a cualquier perturbación. El continente septentrional podría enfrentarse a un déficit energético, y el aumento de los precios del petróleo dispararía la inflación, lo que podría socavar la industria y la agricultura en toda la región. El miembro de la Comisión de Seguridad del Parlamento iraní, Esmail Kosari, afirmó que las autoridades del país ponderan el cierre del estrecho. Según estimaciones de expertos iraníes, esta medida elevará los precios del petróleo hasta los 250 dólares por barril.

title: La inversión directa cae a nivel de 2005 en las economías en desarrollo y de 1996 en las avanzadas
content: Los flujos de inversión extranjera directa (IED) a economías en desarrollo han disminuido al nivel más bajo de 2005, dice el Banco Mundial.
resumen:
Los flujos de inversión extranjera directa (IED) a las economías en desarrollo han disminuido a su nivel más bajo desde 2005 y los dirigidos a las economías de altos ingresos al de 1996, en medio del aumento de barreras comerciales y a la inversión, indicó este lunes el Banco Mundial.

El último año del que hay cifras disponibles son de 2023.

Las economías en desarrollo. Ese descenso hasta los niveles de 2005 coincide con una tendencia a la baja también en los flujos de inversión extranjera directa hacia economías avanzadas: las de altos ingresos recibieron solo 336.000 millones en 2023.

El Banco Mundial eleva seis décimas la previsión de crecimiento de Latinoamérica para 2023, hasta el 2 %.

La IED es una de las formas más productivas de inversión privada.

El Banco Mundial destaca que la IED representó en 2023 aproximadamente la mitad de los flujos de financiación externa recibidos por las economías en desarrollo.

El análisis de datos de 74 economías en desarrollo, entre 1995 y 2019, sugiere que un aumento del 10 % en las entradas de IED genera un crecimiento del 0,3 % en el PIB real al cabo de tres años.

El impacto es casi tres veces mayor (hasta un 0,8 %) en países con instituciones más sólidas, mejor capital humano, mayor apertura comercial y menor informalidad.

China, Brasil e India con los flujos más altos de IED.

Entre 2012 y 2023, aproximadamente dos tercios de los flujos de IED hacia las economías en desarrollo se dirigieron a tan solo 10 países: China recibió casi un tercio del total, Brasil y la India cerca del 10 % y el 6 %, respectivamente, y los 26 países más pobres apenas el 2 %.

La IV Conferencia Internacional sobre Financiación para el Desarrollo (FfD4), que se celebrará en Sevilla (España) del 30 de junio al 3 de julio próximos.

El Banco Mundial emitió de momento tres recomendaciones: redoblar los esfuerzos para atraer IED, como eliminar las restricciones acumuladas en la última década; ampliar los beneficios económicos de esa inversión y dirigirla a sectores donde su impacto es mayor, y fomentar la cooperación global.

title: Alejandro Indacochea: «Se avecina un período de recesión mundial»
content: El próximo 9 de julio de 2025 entra en vigor el arancel de 10% impuesto por la administración del presidente Donald Trump a Perú ...
resumen: El próximo 9 de julio de 2025 entra en vigor el arancel de 10% impuesto por la administración del presidente Donald Trump a Perú tras la suspensión de la medida por 90 días. Estados Unidos es el segundo socio comercial de Perú después de China. Las exportaciones fuertes de Perú son en agroindustria, que son alrededor de 4673 millones de dólares, exportando palta, arándano, uva y espárragos. El otro sector es el sector de textiles y confecciones, exportando textiles de alpaca, lana. Comparativamente, Perú ha salido como uno de los menos afectados en América Latina, junto con Colombia y Chile. El dólar frente al euro ha bajado del 9%, el petróleo ha bajado en 8%, el cobre cayó en casi 10%. Dos bancos de inversión, como es el Goldman Sachs, señalan que la probabilidad de una recesión en Estados Unidos a nivel mundial para los próximos meses es un 37%. Morgan Stanley, señala que es un 40% el fenómeno de recesión. Ecuador quiere sacar por Perú banano y cacao, Colombia no tiene TLC con China y quiere una zona franca acá, de Bolivia son su salida natural, y Chile ya lo anunció, Cosco Shipping va a hacer los traslados de los puertos de Chile para embarcarlos por Chancay. Brasil tiene comercio con Asia por casi el PBI peruano, 250 mil millones de dólares, y exporta más de 150 mil millones. La salida de la soja y de la carne por la zona del Crucero do Sul implica ir al Amazonas, salir al Atlántico y de ahí, ir al canal de Panamá que prácticamente está restringido. La carretera del sur la tenemos hecha. Brasil no tiene TLC con China y aquí en la burocracia peruana, está pendiente la firma del TLC con Brasil.

title: China se volcó en México como solución a la guerra comercial con EEUU. Ahora sus fábricas se están mudando a Brasil o Serbia
content: Los expertos en propiedad industrial de Estados Unidos han notado algo importante: ha habido un "drástico descenso" en las consultas de empresas chinas ...
resumen:
Los expertos en propiedad industrial de Estados Unidos han notado un "drástico descenso" en las consultas de empresas chinas que buscan terrenos para alquilar o comprar en México.

En su primera legislatura como presidente de EEUU, Donald Trump inició a incrementar los aranceles para productos fabricados en China, lo que provocó que las empresas chinas eligieran México como plan B para seguir vendiendo en EEUU, aprovechando el Tratado entre México, Estados Unidos y Canadá (T-MEC o USMCA).

El recrudecimiento de la guerra comercial entre Estados Unidos y otros países, incluyendo México, ha invalidado el tratado, sometiendo a México a aranceles notables del 25%. El T-MEC se revisará el año que viene y ya ha sufrido el impacto de los citados aranceles al hierro y al aluminio.

Los fabricantes de China están comenzando a buscar nuevos destinos para sus fábricas fuera de su país, fijándose en Brasil, Serbia, Hungría y Arabia Saudí.

BYD inició un proyecto para la construcción de una planta de producción de sus vehículos en Bahía (Brasil), que se ha encontrado con problemas. La compañía también cuenta con fábricas en construcción en Szeged (Hungría) y en Manisa (Turquía) que comenzarán a operar en 2026.

En Europa, el interés de China por países como Serbia y Hungría se centra en los sectores de los vehículos eléctricos y las energías renovables. El presidente de China, Xi Jinping, visitó estos países en mayo de 2024.

En 2013 el gobierno de China impulsó la estrategia de desarrollo y cooperación internacional llamada Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). Hungría y Serbia han mantenido su compromiso con la estrategia.

Analistas como Jake Lee afirman que estos movimientos son parte de una estrategia cambiante, reduciendo el foco en EEUU.

La industria de las renovables también busca salida. Ocean Yuan, de la empresa de equipamientos de energía solar Grape Solar, ha visto cómo EEUU amenaza con eliminar los créditos tributarios. Esas compañías están buscando nuevos destinos como los de Oriente Medio.

title: Trump’s Trade and Tax Policies Start to Stall U.S. Battery Boom
content: Battery companies are slowing construction or reconsidering big investments in the United States because of tariffs on China and the proposed rollback of tax credits.
resumen: Battery manufacturing in the United States began to take off in recent years due to generous incentives from Congress and the Biden administration. However, this boom is stalling as the Trump administration and Republican lawmakers try to restrict China’s access to the American market. Companies are slowing construction or reconsidering investments in factories for producing rechargeable batteries and their ingredients. Higher trade barriers between the U.S. and China are fracturing relationships between suppliers and customers. Republicans are seeking to block battery makers with ties to China from taking advantage of federal tax credits. The industry is also dealing with a softening market for electric vehicles, which Republicans and Mr. Trump have targeted. The China-related restrictions, included in the version of Mr. Trump’s domestic policy bill passed by the House, would be very difficult for many companies to operate under. China is the world’s top battery manufacturer and makes nearly all of certain components. The U.S. wants to create a homegrown battery industry and reduce its dependence on China, but China's dominance makes it hard to become a meaningful player without working with Chinese companies. Ford Motor is building a $3 billion battery factory in Marshall, Mich., which is set to start making battery cells next year. Ford is licensing technology from the Chinese battery giant Contemporary Amperex Technology Company, which would make it ineligible for federal subsidies under the House bill. A loss of tax credits “will imperil what we do in Marshall,” according to William Clay Ford Jr., the company’s executive chair. AESC paused construction of a $1.6 billion electric-vehicle battery plant in South Carolina, citing “policy and market uncertainty.” Batteries made there, which are meant to power BMW’s electric vehicles, would soon become ineligible for federal subsidies, in part because a Chinese company owns a large portion of AESC. Those tax credits amount to roughly $3,375 for the average electric vehicle battery, according to UBS. Group14 Technologies slowed construction of a battery materials factory in Moses Lake, Wash., after its customers in China balked at paying higher tariffs. Group14 now expects to start production at the Moses Lake plant early next year, instead of this summer. Mr. Trump and his aides want companies to manufacture more in the United States and want more U.S. mining of critical minerals. The administration is investing in projects that would deliver a return on investment for Americans. The administration would “shore up America’s supply of critical minerals” by investigating imports of such materials on natural security grounds, mining for them offshore and repealing regulations. Electric vehicles have not become as popular in the United States as many companies had expected. Companies canceled more than $6 billion in planned U.S. battery factories in the first quarter, according to Rhodium Group. The Republican policy bill would further erode demand for electric cars by scrapping a $7,500 tax credit available to many people who buy or lease them. If that tax credit goes away, all planned U.S. battery plants will become unnecessary and more than two-thirds of existing capacity could shut down, according to an analysis by the Princeton-led REPEAT Project. Jennifer Granholm, the energy secretary under President Joseph R. Biden Jr., said scrapping clean-energy incentives would cost jobs and undermine U.S. energy security by making the country more dependent on China. Ann E. Harrison, an economist and former dean of the business school at the University of California, Berkeley, said restricting the market is a bad idea. Group14 now expects to start production at its Washington State plant early next year, instead of this summer. title: India's Robust Trade Growth: Navigating Global Shifts

resumen:
India's exports to the US surged in May amid global trade realignments influenced by US-China tensions.
India has reported a significant rise in merchandise exports to the United States, with a 16.93 percent increase amounting to USD 8.83 billion in May.
Imports from the US dipped by 5.76 percent to USD 3.62 billion.
From April to May, the country's exports to the US saw an impressive 21.78 percent surge, totaling USD 17.25 billion.
Imports during this period rose by 25.8 percent to USD 8.87 billion.
The US is now the second-largest trading partner of India, although challenges such as high tariffs on steel, aluminum, and auto parts loom over the horizon.
Exports to other key partners, including China, have also increased significantly.
Economic analysts suggest that the realignment of trade patterns, driven by the ongoing US-China trade war, is influencing India's burgeoning export market, while presenting import risks amidst geopolitical tensions in the Middle East.

title: Tariff War Truce Triggers Shipping Surge

Drewry’s World Container Index showed a 70% spike in just four weeks, with freight costs from Shanghai to Los Angeles up nearly 140% since the end of March. Today’s rates are closer to $5,800 per 40-foot container. In the first quarter of 2025, the global container shipping industry posted nearly $10 billion in profit, which is 83% higher than the same period in 2024. As of this month, there are nine publicly traded container carriers with a market capitalization of at least $10 billion. A recent survey by Freightos of more than 100 small-to-midsize importers shows that 80% of respondents said they’re as or more worried than they were in April. The World Bank revised its global growth forecast downward to 2.3% for 2025.

title: Ccanciller de Venezuela exige el cese de las sanciones
content: Yván Gil pidió ante la Asamblea General de Naciones Unidas que se compensen los "daños, lesiones y pérdidas sufridas" por los países afectados por estas medidas de presión económica.
resumen: El canciller de Venezuela, Yván Gil, exigió el 16 de junio de 2025 ante la ONU el cese inmediato de las sanciones contra su país y pidió reparación por los "daños, lesiones y pérdidas sufridas" para los "Estados afectados" por estas medidas, entre los que mencionó a Cuba. Gil manifestó ante la Asamblea General de la ONU, en la 78ª sesión plenaria, que los Estados responsables de imponer medidas coercitivas deben cesar de inmediato estas medidas ilegales y brindar garantías y seguridades apropiadas de no repetición, así como las reparaciones por todos los daños, lesiones y pérdidas sufridas e infligidas a los Estados afectados y a su población. Aseguró que Venezuela tiene más de 1.000 sanciones aplicadas por el Gobierno estadounidense y sus satélites europeos desde hace 10 años. A juicio del canciller venezolano, las sanciones "representan hoy el mayor obstáculo para la implementación de los planes de desarrollo de las naciones" y "provocan también graves y negativas repercusiones en el ámbito humanitario, amenazando la vida y el bienestar de los pueblos", impidiendo el acceso a los servicios de atención sanitaria, a la adquisición de medicamentos, suministros médicos, equipos y servicios, así como el desarrollo, la compra y el suministro de vacunas. Gil enfatizó que las "medidas coercitivas unilaterales, incluidas aquellas impuestas como instrumentos de coacción política o económica y financiera contra cualquier país, en particular, aunque no exclusivamente, contra los países en desarrollo, son ilegales, además de crueles e inhumanas". Mencionó el "bloqueo económico, comercial y financiero" impuesto contra Cuba por "más de 60 años" como uno de los "ejemplos más infames de esta fracasada política" de sanciones. Instó al gobierno de los Estados Unidos de América a poner fin, de inmediato y sin condiciones, al bloqueo contra Cuba y a excluirlo de la lista arbitraria y unilateral de Estados que supuestamente patrocinan el terrorismo. Denunció una "escalada" de "las prácticas intimidatorias, en particular en forma de supuestos aranceles", en referencia a las medidas tomadas por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump. Advirtió que la aplicación continuada de las sanciones repercutirá "negativamente en la economía mundial" y "causarán y prolongarán el sufrimiento humano", a menos que se "les ponga fin de forma completa, incondicional e inmediata".

title: Cumbre del G7: guerras militares y comerciales en el centro de la agenda del bloque en Canadá
content: Los líderes del Grupo de los Siete se preparan para mantener conversaciones sobre temas comerciales y el conflicto entre Irán e Israel.
resumen: El presidente Donald Trump llegó a las Montañas Rocosas canadienses el domingo por la noche para la cumbre del Grupo de los Siete (G7), expresando optimismo sobre posibles acuerdos comerciales mientras los líderes mundiales se preparan para abordar el tema del conflicto creciente entre Irán e Israel. La reunión en Kananaskis, Alberta, reunirá a los líderes de las mayores economías del mundo en un panorama internacional cada vez más volátil. Marca el regreso al calendario diplomático internacional para Trump, quien ha sorprendido a sus aliados al desafiar las normas e imponer aranceles radicales a amigos y enemigos por igual. El primer ministro canadiense, Mark Carney, había diseñado una agenda destinada a minimizar los desacuerdos dentro del club de las democracias industriales ricas: Gran Bretaña, Canadá, Francia, Alemania, Italia, Japón y Estados Unidos. Esta cumbre del G7 representa una prueba crucial para la cooperación internacional, ya que los líderes enfrentan múltiples crisis simultáneamente. La reunión se produce en un momento crucial en el que las relaciones comerciales globales, la estabilidad en Oriente Medio y las preocupaciones sobre seguridad internacional se entrelazan, lo que podría reconfigurar las alianzas diplomáticas y las asociaciones económicas. «Creo que tendremos algunos acuerdos comerciales nuevos», declaró Trump a los periodistas en la Casa Blanca el domingo al partir hacia la cumbre. La agenda de la cumbre abarca una amplia gama de temas urgentes, como la equidad en el comercio mundial, el acceso a minerales críticos, la migración ilegal, el narcotráfico y la seguridad internacional. Sin embargo, la reunión se ve ensombrecida por la escalada del conflicto entre Israel e Irán tras el sorpresivo ataque israelí contra el liderazgo iraní y las instalaciones nucleares la semana pasada. Las ambiciones comerciales de Trump en el G7 se dan en el contexto de la difícil promesa de su administración de «90 acuerdos en 90 días». Anunciada en abril junto con aranceles radicales, la iniciativa solo ha dado como resultado dos acuerdos hasta la fecha —con el Reino Unido y China—, muy por debajo del ambicioso objetivo de 90 acuerdos antes de la fecha límite del 9 de julio. El secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, declaró la semana pasada que la administración probablemente extendería la pausa de 90 días en la implementación de aranceles para dar más tiempo a las negociaciones con socios comerciales que actúen «de buena fe». El primer ministro canadiense, Mark Carney, ha tomado la decisión sin precedentes de abandonar la práctica anual de emitir un comunicado conjunto al final de la cumbre, lo que refleja el complejo clima diplomático. La cumbre corre el riesgo de convertirse en una serie de conversaciones bilaterales en lugar de una muestra unificada de cooperación internacional. Las incendiarias amenazas de Trump de convertir a Canadá en el «estado 51» y apoderarse de Groenlandia se ciernen sobre el proceso. El presidente francés, Emmanuel Macron, realizó una visita simbólica a Groenlandia el domingo, declarando que el territorio «no se vende» ni «se toma». Otros líderes invitados de India, Ucrania, Brasil, Sudáfrica, Corea del Sur, Australia, México y Emiratos Árabes Unidos se centrarán en evitar posibles aranceles estadounidenses. El presidente Donald Trump sobre las tensiones en Oriente Medio: «A veces tienen que luchar, pero veremos qué pasa. Creo que hay muchas posibilidades de que se llegue a un acuerdo». El presidente francés, Emmanuel Macron, sobre Groenlandia: «Todos en Francia y la Unión Europea piensan que Groenlandia no se vende ni se toma. La situación en Groenlandia es claramente una llamada de atención para todos los europeos». El primer ministro británico, Keir Starmer, sobre la soberanía de Canadá: «Canadá es un país independiente y soberano, y un miembro muy valorado de la Commonwealth». El ex primer ministro canadiense Jean Chrétien sobre la estrategia de Trump: «Tiende a ser un matón. Si Trump decide hacer un espectáculo para salir en las noticias, cometerá alguna locura. Que lo haga y sigamos hablando con normalidad». La cumbre comienza oficialmente el lunes con la reunión bilateral de Trump con Carney, seguida de conversaciones multilaterales a lo largo de la semana. Los líderes mundiales abordarán complejas negociaciones sobre acuerdos comerciales, a la vez que abordan la crisis entre Israel e Irán y el alza de los precios del petróleo.

title: Retos de la economía global
content: Recomienda que ante tantos retos se deben tomar acciones sobre políticas internas y reforzar la resiliencia fiscal a los fines de contener los riesgos inflacionarios.
resumen:
El Banco Mundial en su más reciente informe sobre las perspectivas económicas mundiales revela que la economía mundial enfrenta importantes retos derivados en gran parte del aumento de las tensiones comerciales y la mayor incertidumbre global sobre políticas públicas a formularse.

En el caso de los mercados emergentes y las economías en desarrollo (MEED), las moderadas perspectivas económicas limitan su capacidad para impulsar la creación de empleos y reducir la pobreza extrema.

Ese marco de incertidumbre se agrava por una baja inversión directa extranjera hacia dichos mercados.

Se impone la cooperación mundial para restablecer un entorno comercial internacional más estable y ampliar el apoyo a los países vulnerables, principalmente a los más frágiles y en conflicto.

Se deben tomar acciones sobre políticas internas y reforzar la resiliencia fiscal a los fines de contener los riesgos inflacionarios.

Para fomentar el empleo y el crecimiento a largo plazo, las reformas deben centrarse en mejorar la calidad institucional, atraer inversión privada, fortalecer el capital humano y los mercados laborales.

La economía global se encamina a la peor racha desde 2008 sin considerar las recesiones.

El crecimiento mundial registrará este año su ritmo más lento desde 2008, sin considerar las recesiones mundiales absolutas.

El crecimiento mundial se desacelerará al 2,3% en 2025, casi medio punto porcentual por debajo de la tasa prevista a principios de 2025, a pesar de ello no se vislumbra una recesión mundial.

El crecimiento mundial promedio en los primeros siete años de la década de 2020 será el más lento de todos los decenios desde los años sesenta.

La deuda ha subido a niveles sin precedentes.

El crecimiento se desacelerará en casi el 60% de todas las economías en desarrollo este año y, llegará a un promedio del 3,8% en 2025, antes de subir poco a poco a un promedio del 3,9% en 2026 y 2027.

Los países de ingresos bajos crecerán un 5,3% este año, 2025, lo que supone una disminución de 0,4 puntos porcentuales con respecto a las previsiones de principios de 2025.

La inflación mundial se ve impactada por el aumento de los aranceles y la rigidez de los mercados laborales, que con una proyección del 2,9% en 2025, se mantiene por encima de los niveles previos a la pandemia.

El crecimiento del ingreso per cápita en las economías en desarrollo llegará por debajo del promedio registrado entre 2000 y 2019.

Ante el aumento de las barreras comerciales, las economías en desarrollo deberían tratar de liberalizarse de forma más amplia, estableciendo asociaciones estratégicas para el comercio y la inversión con otras economías.

Diversificar el comercio, incluso mediante acuerdos regionales.

Los responsables de formular políticas deben centrarse en movilizar ingresos internos, priorizar los hogares más vulnerables en el gasto y fortalecer los marcos fiscales.

A fin de acelerar el crecimiento económico, los países deben mejorar el clima para los negocios y promover el empleo productivo, dotando a los trabajadores de las habilidades necesarias, creando condiciones para que los mercados laborales conecten eficientemente con los trabajadores con las empresas.

La colaboración mundial será crucial para apoyar a las economías en desarrollo más vulnerables, a través de intervenciones multilaterales, financiamiento en condiciones concesionarias y, en el caso de los países afectados por conflictos activos, ayuda y apoyo de emergencia.

En América Latina y el Caribe, se anticipa que el crecimiento se mantendrá estable en un 2,3% en 2025, hasta llegar a un promedio de 2,5% en 2026-2027.

Se estima que la economía dominicana crecerá este año 2025 un 4.0%, en 2026 4,2% y 2027 4,4%.

Guyana alcanzará mayores crecimientos en 2025 con un 10%, 2026 23.0% y 2027 24,3%.

Diversos riesgos de deterioro, provocados por las restricciones comerciales adicionales se ciernen ya en América la Latina y el Caribe, zonas que enfrentarán dificultades económicas significativas en 2025 a 2027, apoyadas en el aumento de la inflación.

Los precios de los productos básicos y la demanda mundial desempeñan un papel clave.

La situación global no pinta tan halagüeña y ahora más, por las nuevas conflagraciones bélicas que se desarrollan, específicamente entre Israel e Irán, la cual puede extenderse a otros países o agudizar la situación de las contradicciones entre las potencias mundiales, lo que traería más incertidumbre o inestabilidad e inseguridad globales.

La República Dominicana registra en su haber una dinámica económica y financiera sorprendente.

En mayo las exportaciones registraron cifras significativas con un aumento de 13.4% (Oro y cacao entre los de mayor auge de venta.).

La gobernación del Banco Central Dominicano, resalta el clima idóneo de invertir en el país, atrayendo más turistas, así como más inversiones directas.

Hoy se respira un clima de estabilidad y seguridad jurídica, exportaciones subieron a 8.6% en los primeros cinco meses del año 2025.

Los signos robustos de la economía se mantienen estables en la nación dominicana debido a las excelentes ejecutorias gubernamentales.

El Fondo Monetario Internacional valora el desempeño de la economía dominicana, como las de los países emergentes y en desarrollo como consecuencia de la pausa arancelaria anunciada por la administración Trump, lo que permitirá revisar los porcentajes de crecimiento de las economías hacia arriba, aunque podrían verse afectadas por los últimos enfrentamientos que se suceden entre países beligerantes que ponen en riesgo la estabilidad de las demás naciones.

Las autoridades gubernamentales dominicanas se mantienen pendientes y monitorean palmo a palmo el devenir de los acontecimientos de los entornos, externo e interno, a los fines de evitar sorpresas de desestabilización económica.

El gobierno dominicano explora nuevos mercados para el aumento de las exportaciones y procura eficientizar la administración tributaria para incrementar los ingresos acompañados de la efectividad y eficiencia en el gasto público.

title: Trump Accuses China Of Breaking Trade Agreement After Brief Tariff Truce
content: President Trump claims China violated their trade deal following a temporary 90-day tariff reduction agreement between the world's two largest economies amid ongoing trade tensions.
resumen:
President Trump claims China violated their trade deal following a temporary 90-day tariff reduction agreement between the world's two largest economies amid ongoing trade tensions.

President Donald Trump has publicly accused China of breaching their recent trade agreement.

Trump's allegations follow his decision last month to impose a massive 145 percent tariff on Chinese imports.

In a detailed post on his Truth Social platform, Trump explained his reasoning for initially offering China relief from the punitive tariffs.

Trump now claims that China has completely violated the terms of their agreement.

The trade dispute had appeared to find temporary resolution earlier this month when both nations agreed to reduce their respective tariffs. The United States lowered its tariff rate from 145 percent to 30 percent on Chinese goods, while China reciprocated by reducing its tariffs on American products from 125 percent to 10 percent. This mutual reduction was established as part of a 90-day trial period.

US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent confirmed that trade discussions have stalled and require direct engagement between Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping to achieve progress.

The initial agreement emerged from intensive negotiations held in Geneva, Switzerland. US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer had announced the tariff reductions.

A US trade court recently ruling that Trump exceeded his presidential authority when imposing most tariffs under emergency powers legislation. However, a federal appeals court quickly reinstated the tariffs.

The Trump administration has simultaneously expanded its trade focus to include negotiations with other major economic partners, including Japan, India, and the European Union.

title: Bursa Malaysia to trade at 1,500-1530 this week amid tariff and middle east tensions
content: Bursa Malaysia's key index is set to move between 1,500 and 1,530 nthis week, as markets remain under pressure amid concerns over Washington's planned unilateral tariff letters and escalating tensions ...
resumen: Bursa Malaysia’s key index is set to move between 1,500 and 1,530 this week. Markets remain under pressure amid concerns over Washington’s planned unilateral tariff letters and escalating tensions following Israel’s strike on Iran. Mohd Sedek Jantan, head of investment research at UOB Kay Hian Wealth Advisors Sdn Bhd, said markets are expected to remain vulnerable and trade lower in the near term, unless a meaningful breakthrough occurs over the weekend to de-escalate the conflict. Oil and gas (O&G) stocks may present short-term trading opportunities, particularly those with upstream exposure or companies expanding their upstream concessions. Thong Pak Leng, Rakuten Trade Sdn Bhd equity research vice-president, advised market participants to closely monitor ongoing geopolitical tensions and any developments related to US President Donald Trump’s stance on US-China trade tariffs. The benchmark index is anticipated to trend within the 1,500-1,530 range. If tensions continue to escalate, the second support level is projected at 1,485. For the week just ended, the barometer index rose 1.32 points to 1,518.11 from 1,516.79 a week earlier. The FBM Emas Index gained 14.84 points to 11,370.18, the FBMT 100 Index added 20.35 points to 11,144.04, and the FBM Emas Shariah Index climbed 0.31 of-a-point to 11,329.53. The FBM 70 Index increased 72.14 points to 16,368.71 while the FBM ACE Index fell 32.13 points to 4,487.19. Markets await formal confirmation from Presidents Trump and Xi. Negotiations with the EU, India, Japan, and other partners are still ongoing. COMEX gold prices rebounded sharply to $3,468 per troy ounce on Friday, gaining over 3 percent for the week ended June 13. The MCX Gold Futures on the daily chart opened a gap higher on Friday and reached an all-time high of Rs 1,00,681 per 10 gram. WTI crude oil surged as much as 13 percent, boosted by a 14 percent rally on Friday that pushed prices to $77.62 per barrel. LME base metals posted a mixed performance. Aluminium climbed over 2 percent to close at $2,503 per tonne. Copper edged down 0.5 percent to settle around $9,645 per tonne. The Federal Reserve is widely expected to leave interest rates unchanged at next week’s policy meeting. Key data releases, including US retail sales and Chinese economic indicators, will be closely watched. Kaynat Chainwala is the AVP Commodity Research at Kotak Securities.

title: US Fed set to keep rates unchanged, resisting Trump’s calls for cuts amid economic uncertainty
content: The US central bank is expected to keep interest rates unchanged for a fourth straight policy meeting this week, despite President Donald Trump’s push ...
resumen: The US central bank is expected to keep interest rates unchanged for a fourth straight policy meeting this week, despite President Donald Trump’s push for rate cuts, as officials contend with uncertainty sparked by the Republican’s tariffs. The independent Federal Reserve has started lowering rates from recent highs, but officials have held the level steady this year as Trump’s tariffs began rippling through the world’s biggest economy. The Fed has kept interest rates between 4.25 per cent and 4.50 per cent since December. Trump has slapped a 10 per cent tariff on most US trading partners. Higher rates on dozens of economies are due to take effect in July. Trump has also engaged in a tit-for-tat tariff war with China and imposed levies on imports of steel, aluminium and automobiles. Economists expect it will take three to four months for tariff effects to show up in consumer prices. The unemployment rate has stayed unchanged. The Fed faces growing pressure from Trump to lower rates more quickly. On Wednesday, Trump urged Fed Chair Jerome Powell to slash interest rates by a full percentage point, and on Thursday, he called Powell a “numbskull” for not doing so. Powell has defended US central bank independence over interest rates when engaging with Trump. Fed policymakers have signaled “little urgency” to adjust rates. Economists have warned that Trump’s tariffs would fuel inflation and weigh on economic growth. Analysts expect the central bank to slash rates two more times this year, beginning in September. Ryan Sweet, chief US economist at Oxford Economics, said the Fed is likely to be eyeing data over the summer for inflationary pressures from tariffs. KPMG chief economist Diane Swonk said the US economy is in a different place than during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: This Vermont Town Loves Its Canadian Neighbors. Trump Made Things Complicated.
content: President Trump’s border crackdown and bid for Canada to become the “51st state” have threatened the relationship between Derby, Vt., and Stanstead, Quebec.
resumen:
Jan Beadle, who has lived along the border for 71 years, removed the American flag and hung a Canadian one in its place on her front porch on Canusa Street in Beebe Plain, Vt. She hoped the red maple leaf would send a message to her neighbors in Canada: "I stand with you. And I’m sorry."

The economic impact of Mr. Trump’s trade war with Canada is already palpable on both sides of the border. Economic data shows a steep drop-off in spending by Canadians at Vermont hotels and restaurants; normally, 750,000 Canadian visitors spend $150 million in the state each year. Governors of New England states plan to meet on Monday in Boston with leaders from five Canadian provinces to strategize about the strain in their trade relations.

Since February, Mr. Trump has imposed 25 percent tariffs on some Canadian goods, and repeatedly asserted that Canada would be “better off” as the “51st state.” In response, Canadian officials retaliated by placing 25 percent tariffs on American goods.

Mr. Trump met with Mark Carney, the new prime minister of Canada, at the White House. After Mr. Carney informed the president that Canada “won’t be for sale, ever” — noting hopefully that “the opportunity is in the partnership” — Mr. Trump told him, “Never say never.”

In places like Beebe Plain and neighboring Derby Line, Vt., the breakdown in relations has generated unexpectedly strong feelings. Both places have long taken pride in the border-straddling library they share in Derby Line.

Alexandra Scott, a resident of Stanstead, Quebec, said, “It’s like you have a trusted friend who suddenly reaches out and slaps you. It’s a shocking blow to our economy and psyche, and I don’t know if it will ever be the same.”

The Trump administration ordered new restrictions at the Haskell Free Library and Opera House. After Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, made a surprise visit in January, the administration said that practice would end, and Canadians would need to pass through the local border station with their passports. In response, library leaders resolved to create a new Canadian entrance, a plan that has spurred an outpouring of support from both countries and $220,000 in donations.

Mr. Trump won the town of Derby, which contains the villages of Derby Line and Beebe Plain, in the 2024 election; he also won every other town along the border in Vermont, despite losing the state to former Vice President Kamala Harris by more than 30 percentage points.

Brian Smith, 74, a lifelong resident of Derby and a 25-year member of the town’s governing board who described himself as a “full, 100 percent supporter of Donald Trump,” was troubled enough by recent events to call a joint meeting of officials from Derby and Stanstead, where they resolved to maintain their close relationship.

At Jay Peak, a ski resort five miles from the border in Jay, Vt., where half of all guests have typically come from Canada, Steve Wright, the general manager, has been tracking cancellations at its summer water park and golf course. He recently called 50 Canadian families to ask why they had not renewed their season passes.

In Massachusetts, business with Canada, the state’s top trade partner, generates $13.5 billion per year. Maura Healey, the governor of Massachusetts, said that her state depends on Canadian lumber and energy.

On Canusa Street in Beebe Plain, where Ms. Beadle and her neighbors next door both raised Canadian flags, a letter arrived at both their homes in March. The letter included tickets to an opera performance to be held at the Haskell Library in September.

content: President Donald Trump is issuing a stark warning to Iran against retaliating against U.S. targets in the Middle East while also predicting Israel and Iran would “soon” make a deal to end their ...

Trump predicted “Iran and Israel should make a deal, and will make a deal” and that it could come “soon.”
