Durante la conversación telefónica, ella y Trump también hablaron acerca de las situaciones en Medio Oriente y en Ucrania.

title: BRICS: Vietnam, principal aliado de Pekín contra los aranceles, también se suma
content: El país asiático es una de las economías con mayor crecimiento del mundo y está ofreciendo un impulso decisivo a China en su postura anti-EE.UU.: ha sido admitido en el club de los antiguos países eme ...
resumen: Vietnam ha sido admitido en el club de los antiguos países emergentes como socio junto a Bielorrusia, Bolivia, Cuba, Kazajistán, Malasia, Nigeria, Tailandia, Uganda y Uzbekistán. La adhesión oficial de Vietnam fue anunciada por Brasil, que ostenta la presidencia rotatoria este año. Vietnam tiene una población de casi 100 millones y es miembro estable del G20, con una economía que crece a un ritmo rápido y sostenido (+7% en 2024). Vietnam ha logrado avances significativos en la reducción de la pobreza, reduciendo el porcentaje de población en situación de pobreza del 58,1 % en 1992 al 4,8 % en 2020, y se ha consolidado como uno de los principales productores mundiales de arroz y otros productos agrícolas. Vietnam es uno de los más comprometidos con el desarrollo sostenible, mediante inversiones en tecnología y, en particular, en hidrógeno como fuente de energía alternativa y limpia. La pertenencia de Vietnam al BRICS consolida la alianza con China en una función antiestadounidense. Pekín recurrió a su socio asiático, poniendo en práctica el llamado «transbordo comercial», es decir, el paso de mercancías con destino a Occidente a través de Vietnam, para eludir los aranceles. Vietnam ostenta un superávit comercial con EE. UU. de 123,5 millones de dólares, mientras que hace siete años no alcanzaba los 40 millones. Xi Jinping viajó a Vietnam para cerrar unos cuarenta acuerdos estratégicos con Vietnam, en particular —casualmente— en la cadena de suministro. En el primer trimestre de este año, Vietnam compró 30 millones de dólares en bienes de China y vendió 31,4 millones a Estados Unidos. Los BRICS han pasado de los cinco países que representaban las siglas (Brasil, Rusia, India, China y Sudáfrica) a once miembros de pleno derecho, con la incorporación de Egipto, Etiopía, Indonesia, Irán, Arabia Saudí y Emiratos Árabes Unidos. Los socios son otros diez países "amigos": antes de la nueva entrada de Vietnam, Bielorrusia, Bolivia, Cuba, Kazajistán, Malasia, Nigeria, Tailandia, Uganda y Uzbekistán ya formaban parte del club.

title: Repsol deja de exportar petróleo venezolano a España tras el veto de Trump
content: Las estadísticas de la Corporación de Reservas Estratégicas de Productos Petrolíferos (Cores) confirman que España no trajo ni un solo petrolero a sus ...
resumen:
Las estadísticas de la Corporación de Reservas Estratégicas de Productos Petrolíferos (Cores) confirman que España no importó petróleo venezolano en abril de 2025.
En el primer trimestre de 2025 se importaron desde Venezuela 745.000 toneladas de petróleo venezolano: 299.000 toneladas (enero), 150.000 toneladas (febrero) y 296.000 toneladas (marzo).
En abril, el número de toneladas fue cero.
En abril se compró petróleo de Estados Unidos y México por un valor de 869.000 y 829.000 toneladas respectivamente.
Repsol continúa trabajando en Venezuela extrayendo gas, pero para el consumo local, a través de una joint venture con la italiana Eni.
Una parte del pago que se le hacía a Repsol por dicha extracción es a través de barriles de petróleo que más tarde se exportan.
El consejero delegado de Repsol, Josu Jon Imaz, se reunió con el secretario de Energía de Estados Unidos, Chris Wright, el 4 de junio, en el marco de la Alaska Sustainable Energy Conference (Alaska, EEUU).
Durante la junta general de accionistas de la compañía, Imaz señaló que se seguía «manteniendo un diálogo franco, abierto y sincero» con la Administración del Gobierno de Estados Unidos para continuar operando en el país caribeño.
Otras compañías europeas se han visto implicadas, como la italiana Eni y la francesa Maurel & Prom.
En mayo de 2024 España efectuó la mayor compra de petróleo venezolano de las últimas dos décadas, importando 632.000 toneladas de crudo.
En enero de 2002 se adquirieron 832.000 toneladas de crudo venezolano.
La Administración Trump impuso un arancel del 25% a todos los bienes de cualquier país que importe productos petrolíferos venezolanos.
El arancel caducará un año después de que un país deje de importar petróleo venezolano, o antes si las autoridades lo consideran oportuno.
El empresario Alejandro Hamlyn vinculó con el crudo venezolano a Víctor de Aldama y a la vicepresidenta de Venezuela, Delcy Rodríguez.
El negocio consistía en una sociedad que traería petróleo de Venezuela para su posterior venta en República Dominicana.
Parte de ese petróleo llegó en barco a las aguas de Algeciras (España) tras una operación de ship to ship.

title: California, el polo tecnológico de EEUU que depende de los inmigrantes indocumentados
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, prometió que llevaría a Estados Unidos a una nueva "era dorada", pero por el momento sus medidas están ...
resumen:
En Estados Unidos, el presidente Donald Trump ha prometido una nueva "era dorada", pero sus medidas están afectando la economía, especialmente en California, donde se han producido protestas contra las políticas de inmigración.

California tiene la mayor población inmigrante del país, con más de 10 millones de personas nacidas fuera de Estados Unidos.

Un estudio del Peterson Institute for International Economics concluyó que si la Administración deporta a 1,3 millones de trabajadores sin papeles en 2028, el PIB estaría 1,2 puntos por debajo del nivel en el que se situaría en ausencia de la medida, mientras que si realmente Trump cumple con su promesa, el PIB en 2028 estaría 7,4 puntos por debajo.

La economía de Estados Unidos depende de los trabajadores nacidos en el extranjero, especialmente en California, donde uno de cada tres trabajadores no tiene papeles.

Los sectores que más dependen de los inmigrantes son la construcción, los servicios, los cuidados, la sanidad y la agricultura.

Los inmigrantes ocupan puestos que los jóvenes nacionales no quieren, y las deportaciones no solucionarán el desempleo.

Los inmigrantes han tenido un papel crucial en la economía de Silicon Valley, con más de la mitad de las startups valoradas en 1.000 millones de dólares fundadas por personas de fuera de Estados Unidos.

Trump ha dicho que firmará una orden para hacer frente al efecto de las deportaciones en sectores como la agricultura y los hoteles.

title: Temenos: 77% de las instituciones financieras están invirtiendo en análisis de datos e información impulsada por IA
content: A pesar de la incertidumbre económica y geopolítica, los bancos están invirtiendo en tecnología, con un claro enfoque en la experiencia del cliente, la protección y la innovación.
resumen:
En el Temenos Community Forum '25 en Madrid, Temenos, una firma mundial especializada en tecnología bancaria, presentó los resultados de un estudio global encargado a Hanover Research.

Según el reporte, las instituciones financieras están acelerando las inversiones en tecnología y están poniendo la experiencia del cliente, la innovación y la eficiencia operativa como prioridad en sus agendas estratégicas.

La inversión en tecnología para mejorar la experiencia del cliente se convirtió en la principal prioridad estratégica para el 46% de los bancos de todo el mundo, seguida de cerca por el lanzamiento de nuevos productos y servicios (35%) y la búsqueda de una mayor eficiencia operativa (34%).

El reporte además indica que "ante los rápidos cambios geopolíticos, los bancos necesitan modernizarse para poder predecir, comprender y adaptarse rápidamente a los cambios del mercado; capacidades para las que sus sistemas legados no están equipados. Para satisfacer estas demandas, el 77% de las instituciones financieras están invirtiendo en análisis de datos e información impulsada por IA y el 68% en sistemas de core bancario basados en la nube, todo ello manteniendo un fuerte enfoque en la protección tanto de sí mismas como de sus clientes como prioridad".

En medio de las turbulencias provocadas por la inflación, los aranceles y las tensiones comerciales, la mayoría de los bancos anticipan que aumentarán la inversión en tecnología para proteger mejor a los clientes (84%) y en tecnología para mejorar la eficiencia operativa (81%). Además, tres cuartas partes de los bancos planean aumentar sus inversiones para mejorar la integración de sistemas (75%) y el análisis de datos (73%).

La mayoría de los profesionales (81%) está de acuerdo en que si los bancos no implementan la inteligencia artificial se quedarán atrás de la competencia. Si bien solo el 11% de los bancos han implementado completamente la IA generativa en la actualidad, el 43% está en proceso, lo que indica que más de la mitad está avanzando con una implementación real. En particular, el 60% de los profesionales de la banca ven la IA como una herramienta para aumentar, no para reemplazar, a la fuerza laboral humana.

En su discurso de apertura en el TCF, Isabelle Guis, Chief Marketing Officer (CMO) de Temenos, dijo: "El mensaje es claro: si bien los bancos continúan invirtiendo en modernización, lo están haciendo con una estrecha atención a la evolución de la dinámica del mercado. Las instituciones financieras entienden que mantenerse competitivas significa estar preparadas para adaptarse, y cada vez se reconoce más que si no se adopta pronto la IA podrían quedarse atrás".

La encuesta, realizada por Hanover Research en abril de 2025, capturó las opiniones de 424 altos ejecutivos bancarios de los sectores retail, comercial, de cooperativas de crédito y de gestión de patrimonios. Todos los encuestados ocupaban puestos de nivel directivo o superior en TI o funciones empresariales que supervisaban productos, servicios o estrategias. La encuesta tuvo un alcance global, con participantes de las Américas (53%), Europa (24%), Oriente Medio y África (17%) y Australia/Nueva Zelanda (6%).

title: Sheinbaum confirma reunión con Trump en Canadá: ‘Defenderemos a mexicanos del otro lado de la frontera’
content: Claudia Sheinbaum confirmó este sábado que sostendrá una reunión en la cumbre del G7 con el mandatario estadounidense, Donald Trump.
resumen:
La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, confirmó el sábado 14 de junio que el lunes viajará a Canadá para la cumbre del G-7, donde se reunirá con el mandatario estadounidense, Donald Trump, para defender a los mexicanos del otro lado de la frontera.

En el arranque del programa Salud Casa por Casa en Tlaxcala, Sheinbaum indicó que también defenderá a los mexicanos del país en medio de las redadas que el gobierno de Trump está llevando a cabo en contra de los migrantes.

Se trata del primer encuentro entre los dos líderes desde que asumieron el poder, Trump, en enero de este año, y Sheinbaum, en octubre de 2024.

Sheinbaum indicó: “El lunes nos vamos a una reunión a la que fuimos invitados porque digo en plural porque va el pueblo de México, todo junto (...) Vamos a representar dignamente al pueblo de México. Vamos a una reunión que nos invitaron al G7”.

Explicó que se trata de una reunión a la que acuden las siete principales países del mundo más desarrollados, en las que se incluye a Brasil e India. “Ahí vamos a tener una reunión con el presidente Trump y su equipo”, confirmó. “Que sepan ustedes que ahí vamos a defender dignamente a las y a los mexicanos de aquí y del otro lado de la frontera”, señaló.

Sheinbaum afirmó que se dirige a la reunión con “firmeza” y “convicción”, pero también buscando el “diálogo” y lograr acuerdos para el bienestar de ambos pueblos y naciones, en medio de las tensiones bilaterales por la migración, el comercio y los aranceles.

Sheinbaum indicó: “Vamos(…) a defender a las mexicanas y a los mexicanos, y siempre a decir que cuando estamos juntos, pues somos más fuertes, cuando nos respetamos entre nosotros, somos más fuertes, y eso es lo que vamos a ir a defender”.

“Siempre con la frente en alto, siempre con gallardía porque defendemos y representamos al pueblo de México, un pueblo generoso, valiente, trabajador, que trabaja aquí en nuestro país y también del otro lado de la frontera”, sostuvo.

La reunión internacional se celebrará del 15 al 17 de junio en Kanansakis, en las Montañas Rocosas de Canadá.

title: Where’s the Inflation From Tariffs? Just Wait, Economists Say.
content: It’s a view held by most economists since long before President Trump entered the White House. Prices rose when Mr. Trump imposed levies on China in his first term, though that did not translate to ...
resumen: Tariffs raise consumer prices, a view held by most economists. Prices rose when Mr. Trump imposed levies on China in his first term. Forecasters have been bracing for months for it to happen again on a much larger scale. Data released this week showed that inflationary pressures remained more muted than expected. Economists say that tariffs are affecting prices, but not in a significant enough way to show up in broad measures of inflation like the Consumer Price Index. They argue that the impact will be much more significant this summer. Marc Giannoni, chief U.S. economist at Barclays, said, “Inflation is very likely going to increase.” Mr. Trump’s tariffs have already rippled through the economy in several ways. On Thursday, it announced that steel tariffs would soon apply to appliances made with the metal. This back-and-forth has stirred up anxiety about the economic outlook, sending consumer sentiment plummeting and expectations about inflation higher. April’s inflation reports showed the early imprint of tariffs. The Consumer Price Index rose 0.1 percent in May, or 2.4 percent from a year earlier. The government reported that U.S. wholesale prices had risen the same 0.1 percent last month, registering a 2.6 percent annual pace. Omair Sharif, founder of the research firm Inflation Insights, attributed May’s “seesaw pattern” to the buildup in inventories that retailers amassed earlier this year. The first trade war offers some lessons. Washing machines, which were directly affected by the president’s tariffs in 2018, did not immediately get more expensive. After about five months, the higher costs were passed on nearly “one to one” to consumers, Mr. Sharif said. Shipping costs soared back then as supply chain snarls collided with strong demand for everyday items typically produced overseas. Research conducted by staff at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City showed it took 12 to 18 months for those higher costs to fully pass through to consumer prices. Mr. Sharif said that it could just be a handful of months. Stephen Stanley, the chief U.S. economist at Santander, said, “Price increases are coming. We have lucked out a bit, in that retailers have shown restraint.” By the end of the year, Mr. Stanley expects consumer prices to accelerate to a 3 percent annual pace, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, with big increases in June and July. The milder data could mean that the forthcoming inflation spike may be more contained than once feared. Layoffs are still low, but it is becoming harder for people who want to work to find jobs. Wages are also not growing as fast as they did when inflation was soaring after the pandemic. Airline fares dropped again in May. Thomas Simons, chief U.S. economist at Jefferies, said, “Given that we’ve had inflation increase so much over the last few years cumulatively, I think there’s significantly higher resistance among consumers to accept higher prices.” Mr. Giannoni at Barclays does not expect tariff-related costs to be fully passed along to consumers. The Federal Reserve is widely expected to hold interest rates at 4.25 percent to 4.5 percent, the level in place since January. Fed officials believe tariffs will raise inflation while denting growth. If the inflationary effects of tariffs end up far more benign than initially expected, the Fed would have more flexibility to restart interest rate cuts sooner. Mr. Giannoni said, “I would be very, very surprised if we don’t see some stronger inflation prints in the next several months.”

title: Charting Japan’s ‘third path’ under Trump 2.0
content: Under Trump’s reciprocal tariff agenda, Japan can champion a ‘third path’ between the US and China through the CPTPP.
resumen: Japan is responding to the assertive and protectionist trade policies of a second Trump administration by pursuing a ‘third path’ that centres on strengthening rules-based economic frameworks through the CPTPP and entering into deeper cooperation with European, Commonwealth and Indo-Pacific partners. The Trump administration’s trade policy represents a long-term transformation of the global trade landscape, which demands not only resilience but a proactive diversification of strategic partnerships and the reinforcement of rules-based economic governance. The Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) has gained renewed relevance for Japan. The United Kingdom formally acceded to the CPTPP in December 2024, expanding its membership to 12 countries with a combined population of 593 million. The CPTPP represents a ‘third path’ for Japan. Japan has chosen the third option, anchoring its economic security strategy in the CPTPP and expanding cooperation with European, Commonwealth and Indo-Pacific partners. The CPTPP has been recognised as a tool to counter economic coercion. Japan should advance a three-pronged strategy to operationalise this framework. First, it should deepen economic integration with ASEAN and encourage emerging Southeast Asian economies to adopt CPTPP norms. Second, Japan must align regulatory standards with the European Union, particularly in digital governance and sustainability, leveraging the United Kingdom as a bridge. Tokyo should also extend CPTPP cooperation into Latin America. The CPTPP’s membership is largely made up of exporters and without the United States, the pact lacks a large consumer market that could absorb members’ trade surpluses. Within the CPTPP, efforts to reconfigure supply chains may generate friction among members. China’s formal application for CPTPP membership could divide the group unless strict accession criteria are upheld. Japan has a unique opportunity to play an important role in salvaging the rules-based, inclusive economic order, paving a ‘third path’ beyond the binary choice between Washington and Beijing. By leveraging the CPTPP as a geopolitical asset and expanding its reach across Asia, Europe, the Commonwealth and Latin America, Japan can define a new architecture of global economic governance. Satoru Kohda is Senior Fellow at Deloitte, Tokyo. Ayaka Hiraki is Research Fellow at Deloitte, Tokyo and PhD candidate at Keio University, Tokyo.

title: What Goldman CEO David Solomon is thinking
content: Business leaders are feeling better about President Donald Trump’s agenda than they were in the aftermath of the “Liberation Day” tariff announcements.
resumen:
Business leaders are feeling better about President Donald Trump’s agenda than they were in the aftermath of the “Liberation Day” tariff announcements.

CEOs are starting to plan for 2026 with an incomplete roadmap on how major economic policies will shake out.

Goldman Sachs Chairman and CEO David Solomon said, “At the moment, there’s a sense that things are moving forward constructively.”

Solomon said in an interview shortly after Trump touted a new agreement with China that represented a further de-escalation in trade tensions.

Solomon said, “People would like the level of certainty around the policy direction to continue to increase.”

Hours after the China framework was unveiled — and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told lawmakers that the administration would likely delay its July 8 deadline for trade negotiations— the president said he would unilaterally set tariff rates in the coming weeks.

Wall Street banks and the overall economy have fared well despite the uncertainty generated by abrupt changes to tariff rates and Congress’s stop-and-start progress on the “big, beautiful bill” that’s at the center of Trump’s domestic agenda.

Solomon was bullish on Goldman’s pipeline and said both the economy and deal activity have proven “more resilient than I would have expected.”

Trump, along with top administration officials like Bessent, have pointed to the string of recent economic data as a sign that the administration’s overall agenda is working — despite the bellyaching of most economists — and that growth should accelerate when the tax and spending bill is enacted.

Solomon shares the administration’s perspective that current tax cuts should be extended.

With bond investors skittish about how the legislation could affect deficits, the banker said that the long-term outlook for future economic growth is hazy.

Solomon said, “We’re in a place where we’ve increased our debt and deficit levels. And there doesn’t seem to be a path — at the moment — to reducing them.”

Solomon said, “That’s something that I think we’re going to have to wrestle with. And it’s something that, over time, has the potential to crowd out investment and slow down growth.”

Solomon added, “Can we have a higher level of growth that can make it easier for us over time to absorb the spending levels and the deficit levels that we have? That’s unclear at this point and time.”

Trump lashed out at Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell once again over interest rate policy on Thursday, labeling the central banker a “numbskull” for not reducing borrowing costs.

Trump said, “We’re going to spend $600 billion a year, $600 billion because of one numbskull that sits here [and says] ‘I don’t see enough reason to cut the rates now.’”

Trump said, “Let’s say there was inflation. In a year from now, raise your rates. I don’t mind, raise your rates. I’m all for it. I’ll be the one to be calling you.”

Trump also raised expectations for when his administration will broker a comprehensive trade agreement with China.

House Republicans have narrowly advanced a request from the White House to claw back $9.4 billion that lawmakers have already approved for public media and more than a dozen accounts across the State Department focused on foreign assistance.

Low-income households stand to lose as much as $1,600 a year in federal resources due to cuts in the House version of Trump’s “big, beautiful bill.

Annual resources to the highest-income households would climb by $12,000.

The CBO and projections from the Penn Wharton Budget Model and Yale Budget Lab have consistently estimated that the legislation will add to the deficit over the next decade.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told Senate Finance lawmakers on Thursday that he expects the opposite to occur.

The claims from 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue go as high as $8 trillion in black ink (an $11 trillion chasm with the experts) in claims that go beyond what even Capitol Hill Republicans are projecting.

Senate Republicans may leave out the House’s higher state-and-local tax deduction from its version of the bill in order to allow negotiations to continue.

Senate Finance Chair Mike “Crapo and I had a long conversation about it,” said Sen. Markwayne Mullin (R-Okla.).

Senate Banking Chair Tim Scott (R-S.C.) threw cold water on Texas Republican Sen. Ted Cruz’s effort to include language in the megabill that would bar the Fed from paying interest to banks.

The Senate’s landmark stablecoin legislation moved one step closer to passage on Thursday, clearing a procedural vote 67-30.

The Senate voted along party lines to confirm Billy Long to be the next head of the Internal Revenue Service.

The former six-term Missouri congressman will enter the tax agency “during a period of upheaval” due to workforce reductions and an overhaul of its technology systems.

The pace and volume of regulatory shifts that have occurred so far this year are creating “unanticipated business risks,” according to KPMG’s mid-year report.

Amy Matsuo, the consulting firm’s U.S. regulatory insights leader, said in a statement, “Growing regulatory divergence and fragmentation add another layer of complexity to establishing a clear path from strategy and operations to effective risk and compliance.”

title: Jamie Dimon Warns Economic Deterioration Awaits
content: “I think there’s a chance real numbers will deteriorate soon." ...
resumen:
Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase, warned about the economic road ahead.

He cautioned that troubling conditions may soon emerge as pandemic-era funding dries up and the lingering effects of Trump administration tariffs begin to surface in the data.

Speaking at a company conference on June 10, Dimon said, “I think there’s a chance real numbers will deteriorate soon. Employment will come down a little bit. Inflation will go up a little bit. Hopefully, just a little bit.”

Dimon pointed to a recent surge in the U.S. workforce, which has added eight million people over the past few years. Factoring in the four to five million who lost jobs during the pandemic and have since returned, that still leaves an additional three to four million workers—roughly 1.5 to 2 million each year.

Dimon warned that at some point, such rapid growth could slow the economy.

Dimon stressed that he tries not to be distracted by routine fluctuations, focusing instead on the major forces that shape the nation’s future, such as military and global economic alliances.

When pressed on what he meant by “soon,” Dimon pointed to the early signs of tariff impacts now beginning to appear. Companies and consumers had been stockpiling goods to get ahead of tariffs—a trend that, according to Dimon, amounted to about $1 billion in purchases each day.

Dimon noted that sentiment is an unreliable predictor.

For Dimon, the most significant red flag is leverage, and by extension, government deficit levels. In the U.S., a key indicator of investor confidence is the yield on the 10-year Treasury Note, which has been volatile, recently hovering between 4.3% and 4.4%. The yield has remained elevated since September 2023.

title: Can The U.S. Economy Right The Ship In Wake Of Tariffs And Market Uncertainty?
content: With the fifth anniversary of the pandemic behind us, many might be surprised to learn that the $5.3 trillion fiscal response remains a fundamental driver of today’s economy. The U.S. pandemic fiscal ...
resumen: The first 100 days of the second Trump Administration have injected a healthy amount of market uncertainty. Initial tariffs created a catalyst for a market correction, and financial experts are questioning whether the economy is on the brink of recession. Resolving trade differences with Europe and China, and codifying a sweeping tax bill to provide relief to the middle class are essential for the health of the economy. The $5.3 trillion fiscal response to the pandemic remains a fundamental driver of today’s economy, equivalent to roughly 25% of the 2020 nominal GDP. The first year of a new administration brings an average market return of 7%, and the first year of a second term provides an average 9.7% market return. Mark Zandi, Moody’s Analytics chief economist, warned of potential headwinds, citing that immigration and tariff policy could bring unintended consequences, including tax increases and job loss. The initial 25% tariffs on EU cars, steel, and aluminum and 20% broader goods in April have been delayed until early July. Early estimates show that—on net—Trump’s tax cuts are modestly more stimulative than his tariffs are restrictive. The House GOP’s version would boost long-run GDP by 0.8% and add approximately 983,000 jobs. Trump’s tariff plans would lower long-run GDP by 0.8% and cost 713,000 jobs. The combination of tax cuts and tariffs may result in a net addition of 270,000 jobs to the economy and neutral impact on growth. Consumers will find the most straightforward, cheapest utility of what they want: bearing the brunt of cost increases without dramatically changing their behavior.

title: Trump says he will set new tariff rates
content: President Donald Trump said he intended to send letters to trading partners in the next one to two weeks setting unilateral tariff rates ahead of a July 9 deadline to reimpose higher duties on dozens ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump said he intended to send letters to trading partners in the next one to two weeks setting unilateral tariff rates ahead of a July 9 deadline to reimpose higher duties on dozens of economies.

Trump told reporters Wednesday at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington that he would be sending letters out in about a week and a half, two weeks, to countries, telling them what the deal is.

Trump said he would be open to extending the deadline for nations to cut deals with his administration before higher levies take effect.

Trump in April announced higher tariffs on dozens of trading partners only to pause them for 90 days.

The only trade framework the U.S. has reached is with the U.K., along with a tariff truce with China.

Trump earlier Wednesday said the trade framework with China had been completed and would have Beijing supply rare earths and magnets, with the U.S. allowing Chinese students to study at American colleges and universities.

Trump's team is also working to secure bilateral deals with India, Japan and South Korea as well as the European Union.

Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said earlier Wednesday that the European Union is likely to be among the last deals that the U.S. completes.

Trade officials from India and the U.S. have hardened their stance on some key issues as they race to conclude an interim deal before higher U.S. tariffs take effect in July.

Negotiators from both sides met in New Delhi this week.

The U.S. wants India to eliminate tariffs and ease price controls on medical devices and relax rules on data localization policy.

New Delhi is pushing for the U.S. to exempt India from existing sectoral tariffs on steel and automobiles and threatened reciprocal tariffs that are scheduled to kick in on July 9.

India also wants to be exempted from proposed duties on pharmaceuticals.

Trump has launched investigations in the pharmaceuticals sector under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act.

A U.S. trade team led by Brendan Lynch, assistant U.S. Trade Representative, met officials in New Delhi on June 5-10.

India and the U.S. are working on a phased trade deal with an early agreement targeted for July.

title: Savannah banking on other Asian shipping to offset China tariff storm
content: Savannah, Georgia's port has grown the fastest on the East Coast in recent years, lifted by ships from China. It's got a plan to ride out the tariff war.
resumen:
Savannah's rise as a port city began with Maersk shipping line becoming a regular visitor in 2000, followed by other carriers. By 2007, Savannah was the second-busiest port along the Atlantic seaboard. Today it is the fastest-growing port on the East Coast.

China joined the World Trade Organization in 2001, and Savannah's port growth paralleled China’s rise as a U.S. trading partner. China accounts for nearly 40% of the port’s imports.

Imports from China dropped 28.5% nationally in May. Savannah vessel calls have dipped in recent weeks. Authority CEO Griff Lynch has projected June container volumes to be down significantly from the same month a year ago.

The Georgia Ports Authority is banking on its growing business with other Asian countries to weather the trade storm.

Savannah’s trans-Atlantic traffic has nearly doubled since 2019 and now makes up more than 40% of imports, much of it fueled by India, Vietnam, Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia.

China’s share of Savannah’s overall container volume has been declining for years, from 48% in 2018 to 33%.

U.S. tariffs on China’s exports have gyrated between 30% and 145% in recent months.

The China Plus One strategy emerged in 2013.

Ocean Network Express, or ONE, has operated a route between Savannah and India since June 2024, with vessels calling weekly.

Savannah’s port trade with India is up 50% over the last five years and India now accounts for about 7% of all traffic.

Nils Haupt with German shipping line Hapag-Lloyd AG, a frequent Georgia ports user, said Savannah is a highly efficient port.

Walter Kemmsies, a Savannah-based maritime trade consultant, said Savannah is going to come off better from the divorce with China than other ports.

According to the National Retail Federation’s Jonathan Gold, Trump’s “Liberation Day” tariff threats against countries enjoying manufacturing gains under the China Plus One shift have forced a “standstill.”

West Coast ports handle as much as 75% of China’s cargo traffic.

Most shipping lines have been bypassing the Suez Canal since Houthi militants began firing missiles at cargo vessels in late 2023.

When the Suez is open, moving goods from India and its neighbors to Savannah takes about the same time as shipping cargo from China to Savannah across the Pacific Ocean and through the Panama Canal.

Ocean carriers have been routing around the southern tip of Africa instead, adding 10 days to the trans-Atlantic transit.

The Georgia Ports Authority’s Lynch said that an end to the Houthi conflict would create a “West Coast-East Coast” story for maritime trade in the U.S.

title: US dollar hits multi-year low as analysts warn of dangers of Trump policies
content: The US dollar is on the slide, while investors are shying away from the world's reserve currency and traders grow increasingly uncertain about Donald Trump's economic policy.
resumen: The US dollar has hit a multi-year low. Investors are seeking alternative currencies like the euro. The decline in the US dollar has meant continued currency market support for the Australian dollar. Currency traders are looking for trade war developments, an update on the US fiscal position, and the outlook for global interest rates. The US dollar is under renewed pressure, probing multi-year lows. InTouch senior FX analyst Sean Callow said the US dollar started 2025 with strong momentum as investors priced in a 'Trump trade' of dollar gains, backed by loose fiscal policy supporting growth and making the Fed reluctant to cut rates. Things started to unravel in March as Trump's tariff campaign proved more aggressive than expected and administration officials said they were willing to tolerate a weaker economy in the short term. Recession fears surged on the April 2 tariff announcement, hurting the dollar's yield support. This dynamic also led to an enormous US Treasury bond sell-off as global investors began to question the durability of the United States' fiscal position. This pushed investors into the euro. The sell-off in long-term Treasuries raised fears of a 'Sell America' trade, largely benefiting the euro. USD weakness has helped the Aussie [dollar] push above 65 cents, reaching highs since November. The US Dollar Index (DXY) hit its lowest level since January 2022 on Thursday at 97.8 at 9pm AEST. The Aussie [dollar] is not investors' preferred alternative to the US dollar. It is the weakest major currency so far in 2025. Further US dollar weakness and Australian dollar strength may depend on how currency traders view the credibility of the Trump administration's policies. title: Israel/Iran attack could add 12c/L to petrol, Tariffs, Migration, Low equity risk premiums, Productivity
content: By Dr Shane Oliver, Chief Economist and Head of Investment Strategy at AMP. Investment markets and key developments Global shares had a messy week pushed around by tariff news in the US, better than ...
resumen: Global shares fluctuate as Middle East tensions rise, US trade policies remain unclear. Israel’s attack on Iran’s nuclear capabilities could add 12 cents a litre for Australian petrol prices. Oil prices surged around 16% on fears of supply disruptions by Iran. The US and China agreed a rather vague “framework to implement the Geneva consensus” but tariffs remain. Trump’s threat to put the tariffs on China back up again if no fundamental deal is reached by 12 August. The US Appeals Court extended the stay on the Trade Court’s ruling that the bulk of Trump’s tariffs were illegal. Trump has reiterated that he will set unilateral take it or leave it tariff rates for trading partners in two weeks. Trump has also floated raising the auto tariff from 25% and more sectoral tariffs are still on the way. Trump may be setting up an off ramp from the trade war by pivoting to immigration. The bottom line remains that shares have had a good rebound – with US and global shares getting within 2% of a new high and the ASX 200 making a record high – but macroeconomic risk flowing from Trump’s policies and the latest Israel/Iran flare up are high, so the ride is likely to remain volatile in the near term. The Government’s announcement of a productivity summit in August to create consensus around an agenda to boost productivity is good news. Top of the list of reforms to boost productivity should be: Tax reform, Limit government spending below 25% of GDP, Deregulate product and labour markets, Provide more incentives to invest & adopt new technology, Boost workforce capability by improving education and training outcomes, Competition reform to reduce market concentration, Match population growth to the ability to supply new homes and make it easier to live away from congested cities, Boost service delivery productivity in the care economy, Rely on market signals as to how best to move to net zero. US inflation came in weaker than expected in May with the core CPI up just 0.1%mom and remaining at 2.8%yoy. The good news on inflation won’t be enough to tip the Fed over into a rate cut just yet. China remained in deflation in May. Chinese exports slowed less than expected in May. The June Westpac/MI consumer survey showed a rise in confidence, helped by the latest RBA rate cut. The NAB business survey showed a sharp fall in employment plans. The RBA is likely to look through any boost to inflation as temporary and focus more on any drag to growth. Our base case is for 0.25% rate cuts in July, August, November and February taking the cash rate to 2.85%. The money market sees about an 88% chance of a 0.25% cut in July and just over three cuts by year end. In the US the Fed (Wednesday) is expected to leave the Fed Funds rate on hold at 4.25-4.5%. The Bank of England (Thursday) is expected to leave rates on hold at 4.25%. The Swedish central bank (Wednesday) is expected to cut its cash rate by 0.25% to 2% and the Swiss central bank (Thursday) is expected to cut by 0.25% to zero. The Bank of Japan (Tuesday) is expected to remain on hold at 0.5%. Australian jobs data (Thursday) for May is expected to show employment growth of 10,000 and unemployment rising to 4.2%. Shares are at high risk of renewed falls. Bonds are likely to provide returns around running yield or a bit more. Australian home prices have likely started an upswing on the back of lower interest rates. Cash and bank deposits are expected to provide returns of around 4%. The $A is likely to be buffeted between the negative impact of US tariffs and the global trade war and the potential positive of a further fall in the overvalued US dollar.

title: China y EE. UU. vuelven al punto cero tras guerra comercial iniciada por Trump
content: Administración Trump vuelve a retroceder. Según The New York Times, ambas potencias revirtieron algunas medidas tomadas en mayo tras la guerra comercial iniciada por el presidente estadounidense.
resumen:
China y EE. UU. vuelven al punto cero tras guerra comercial iniciada por Trump.
Según The New York Times, ambas potencias revirtieron algunas medidas tomadas en mayo tras la guerra comercial iniciada por el presidente estadounidense.
Incluso si el acuerdo se mantiene, significa que la situación se vuelve al punto inicial, antes de que el presidente Donald Trump aumentara los aranceles al gigante asiático.
Estados Unidos y China habrían desescalado su guerra comercial.
De acuerdo al The New York Times, funcionarios de ambos países lograron un acuerdo en la madrugada del miércoles en Londres.
Las partes se habrían comprometido a revertir algunas medidas impuestas en los últimos meses.
A pesar del avance, aún no es garantizado que estas decisiones se mantengan en el futuro.
Incluso si el acuerdo se mantiene, significa que la situación se vuelve al punto inicial, antes de que el presidente Donald Trump aumentara los aranceles al gigante asiático.
“Parece que estamos negociando en círculos”, indicó Myron Brilliant, asesor principal en DGA-Albright Stonebridge Group y exvicepresidente ejecutivo de la Cámara de Comercio de EE. UU.
“Escalas, desescalas”, agregó.
“Al final del día, no hemos avanzado realmente”.
Los aranceles se mantendrán, mientras que se podrían revertir las políticas que ambas potencias tomaron en mayo.
Se espera que el país asiático flexibilice las restricciones sobre la exportación de minerales, las cuales afectan a fabricantes estadounidenses.
El país norteamericano suavizará los límites a sus exportaciones de tecnologías, así como la amenaza de cancelar visas a estudiantes chinos.

title: Respaldo de Trump y empresas de EE. UU. a manufactura textil de zonas francas locales
content: Nuestro país debe recibir con beneplácito esta noticia publicada en junio 4, 2025: “Trump y productores textiles de USA han decidido aportar a la manufactura ...
resumen:
En junio 4, 2025 se publicó la noticia de que Trump y productores textiles de USA han decidido aportar a la manufactura textil de zonas francas dominicanas y otros países de la región sin tomar en cuenta temas de competencia.

Las zonas francas dominicanas están ubicadas sólidamente dentro de las productoras de equipos médico eléctricos y electrónicos.

Siguiendo el esquema de desarrollo de Corea del Sur, USA cooperará para que República Dominicana siga el mismo tipo de desarrollo.

El país se encuentra en una fase de desarrollo tecnológico intermedio que ya desbordó la producción de material textil.

Las zonas francas superaron el procesamiento del material textil hace varias décadas cuando perdió vigencia el "acuerdo multifibras".

Las zonas francas también se dedicaron a la producción de calzado.

La producción de textiles supondría un retroceso tecnológico.

Las zonas francas están acercándose a la etapa en que pudieran dedicarse a la producción, ensamblaje o inspección de microconductores.

En la década de los 80 un grupo económico dominicano intentó convertir el país en un importante actor en el área textil partiendo desde la etapa inicial sembrando algodón en el norte del país con su empresa “Algodón Dominicano” (Algodom).

El cultivo de algodón en República Dominicana coincidió con la siembra de algodón de China Continental.

La oferta de Trump de apoyar la manufactura textil de zonas francas dominicanas es estimulante si se compara con los altos aranceles que Trump ha señalado a las importaciones de muchos países del mundo.

En abril 25 2025 se escribió un artículo titulado “Aranceles, comercio RD-USA y actuaciones de presidentes Reagan y Trump”.

Altos aranceles para los productos exportables a USA harían desaparecer el esquema de zonas francas dominicanas que ha sido exitoso creando actualmente 200,000 empleos directos.

Cada empleo da sustento a cada familia con promedio de 5 personas, las zonas francas dan sustento a 1,000,000 de dominicanos que son el 10% del total de la población dominicana.

Dentro de pocos años se tendrán empresas similares a las Surcoreanas LG y Samsung.

title: Niño Becerra, economista predice un colapso en verano: "Paralización de la economía mundial"
content: La economía española atraviesa un momento de creciente incertidumbre: con la inflación desbocada, el aumento en los precios de los alimentos, el encarecimiento de las hipotecas y un nuevo escenario in ...
resumen:
Niño Becerra, economista predice un colapso en verano: "Paralización de la economía mundial".
La economía española atraviesa un momento de creciente incertidumbre: con la inflación desbocada, el aumento en los precios de los alimentos, el encarecimiento de las hipotecas y un nuevo escenario internacional marcado por los aranceles de Donald Trump están generando una sensación de fragilidad económica.
El reconocido economista Santiago Niño Becerra ha lanzado una advertencia: podríamos vivir una paralización de la economía mundial similar a la de la pandemia.
Niño Becerra enciende las alarmas: «Si vamos a peor, en verano podemos llegar a una situación Covid de paralización de la economía mundial».
Donald Trump asumía nuevamente el poder en Estados Unidos el pasado dos de abril y, como parte de sus primeras medidas, anunciaba una agresiva política arancelaria dirigida contra numerosos países.
En España estas decisiones tienen efectos directos: tensiones comerciales, encarecimiento de las importaciones y, en consecuencia, un impacto negativo sobre el poder adquisitivo de los ciudadanos.
Santiago Niño Becerra, catedrático de Estructura Económica en el Instituto Químico de Sarriá de la Universidad Ramón Llull de Barcelona desde 1994, ha hecho públicas sus inquietudes respecto al rumbo que podría tomar la economía global.
Mostrando un gráfico del índice Standard & Poor’s (S&P), ha recordado que uno de los momentos más críticos se vivió en 2008, cuando el índice cayó hasta los 735 puntos.
El récord histórico se ha alcanzado en 2025, con 6.101 puntos.
El economista ha advertido sobre una posible recaída: "si empeora, con más aranceles y sus consecuencias, podríamos llegar en verano a una situación similar a la vivida durante la pandemia: una paralización de la economía mundial".

title: ASEAN eyes rail connectivity to boost regional trade amid global tensions
content: A seamless and reliable regional rail freight service is seen as vital to increasing the bloc’s total trade volume, which is projected to reach US$4.5 trillion by 2030.
resumen: ASEAN is focusing on strengthening regional connectivity to boost trade amid global tensions. A seamless and reliable regional rail freight service is seen as vital to increasing the bloc’s total trade volume, which is projected to reach US$4.5 trillion by 2030. The Laos-China Railway, a 414km railway line constructed under China's Belt and Road Initiative, was launched in December 2021. The railway cost almost US$6 billion. The Laos section spans over 400km, while the China stretch to Kunming spans almost 600km. Tourist arrivals in Laos increased more than 30 per cent to 4 million last year. The Thanaleng Dry Port, which began operations in tandem with the railway launch, has handled more than 200,000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs). Last year, the volume of TEUs it handled grew by 30 per cent from 2023. The difference in rail gauges between Laos and Thailand presents a technical challenge. In April, the dry port signed a memorandum of understanding with Malaysia’s soon-to-be-operational Perlis Inland Port, which is expected to handle up to 300,000 container boxes annually when it is ready in mid-2026. The ASEAN Rail Express, a cargo rail service launched mid last year, failed to take off and was suspended. Malaysia’s Transport Minister Anthony Loke met with his Thai counterpart in Bangkok to form a joint ministerial committee tasked with improving trade facilitation for goods in transit. Industry players are looking forward to the resumption of the ASEAN Rail Express, which could reduce travel time by up to 40 per cent compared with sea shipping.

title: China’s yuan slips as Middle East tensions rise
content: SHANGHAI: China’s yuan eased against the US dollar on Friday, retreating from a more than two-week high reached overnight, as the greenback rebounded after Israel launched strikes on Iran. Escalating ...
resumen:
China’s yuan eased against the US dollar on Friday, retreating from a more than two-week high reached overnight, as the greenback rebounded after Israel launched strikes on Iran.

Escalating tensions in the Middle East dented global risk appetite, prompting investors to flock to safe-haven assets such as gold and the US dollar.

The spot yuan opened at 7.1799 per dollar and was last trading at 7.1767 as of 0253 GMT, 52 pips lower than the previous late session close.

The People’s Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 7.1772 per dollar, its strongest since March 28 and 87 pips weaker than a Reuters’ estimate.

The spot yuan is allowed to trade 2% on either side of the fixed midpoint each day.

The onshore yuan firmed in the late night session on Thursday, hitting its strongest since May 26, as the dollar index fell to its lowest in over three years on weaker-than-expected US inflation data.

China’s trade-weighted CFETS yuan basket index fell to 95.49, the lowest since July 2023, according to Reuters estimates.

The offshore yuan has firmed towards 7.17 amid broader US dollar weakness and an improved outlook after the US and China reached agreement on a trade framework.

An index that measures the dollar against six other currencies rose 0.45% and was last at 98.12.

The offshore yuan traded at 7.1794 yuan per dollar, down about 0.09% in Asian trade.

title: Multipolarity: Shaping the investment landscape for decades to come
content: A dramatic shift in global dynamics is reshaping economic and financial landscapes, setting the stage for profound, long-term change. As new policies and leadership redefine the world order, investors ...
resumen: The world order shift highlighted by Donald Trump's second term has become a key investment theme that will shape the global economy and financial markets for decades to come. Investors should expect a more fragmented world where national strategic interests dominate. After World War II, the United States was the dominant global economy. With China’s accession to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) formalised in 2001, the triumph of the US world order appeared complete. China has grown in size and poses an ever-growing military and technological threat to the US. The new world order is one marked by a rising challenger in the form of China and a number of regional powers ranging from the European Union (EU) and Russia to emerging giants like Brazil, India and Indonesia. This is a far more fragmented world, in which the US is in retreat from global affairs, while China and other regional powerhouses are increasingly asserting their influence. A defining feature of the unipolar world in the post-WWII era was globalisation. Since the 2008 Global Financial Crisis, globalisation has been in retreat. The Covid pandemic laid bare the vulnerability of global supply chains to disruption. Trade tariffs, restrictions on foreign investment and national industrial policies, including subsidies, will increasingly shape the global economy. Trump is using tariffs to force both friend and foe to align with the US’s strategic interests. China is asserting its influence through strategic initiatives like the One Belt One Road programme. The cost to the world is likely to be less efficient production, higher prices and slower global growth. A benefit of the post-WWII era, particularly after the decline of the Soviet Union, was the US’s ability to police the world. In the US, military spending fell from 9% of GDP in 1960 to less than 4% by 2023, while total global military spending fell from 6% of GDP in 1960 to 2% in 2023. A multipolar world is likely to be more prone to conflict and regional powers will assert their influence, in part, through military power. The higher share of GDP allocated to military spending requires a reduction elsewhere and, to the extent that it is financed by government borrowing, adds to the risk premium investors are likely to demand for holding long-term government bonds. The retreat from globalisation and greater spending on military and defence are both likely to be inflationary. Regional powers will focus on national strategic interests. The US government is prioritising building national security in chip supply. The Covid pandemic demonstrated the vulnerability of global ‘just-in-time’ supply chains and now governments are focused on building national resilience, even if it comes at the expense of higher costs of production. TSMC estimates that producing 4nm chips at its Arizona plant is about one third more expensive than producing them at its plants in Taiwan. Minerals like cobalt, copper, lithium, nickel and rare earth metals are vital to the transition to clean energy. Deglobalisation, through fragmentation of global supply chains, increased competition over scarce resources such as chips and critical minerals, and increased military spending, are all likely to encourage a greater role of government in the economy and drive inflation. Since the 1970s, the fall in the dependency ratio (the ratio of non-working-aged population to the working-aged population) has been a significant factor driving lower inflation in the global economy. Dependency ratios are rising globally, including in China. The combination of deteriorating demographics and the retreat in globalisation means the odds are tilted towards higher medium-term inflation. Inflation in developed economies is unlikely to settle back at the sub-2% levels that prevailed before Covid. Another possible outcome of Trump’s second term might well be an increase in foreign distrust of the US and its institutions. Central banks’ holdings of gold have spiked since Russia’s foreign currency reserves were frozen by Western powers following its invasion of Ukraine. Over the longer term, the share of global central bank foreign currency reserves held in US dollars also appears to be gradually declining. Any erosion of trust in the US under Trump’s administration is likely to see these trends accelerate, undermining the role of the US dollar as a reserve currency and supporting the fundamental case for holding gold. The shift to a multipolar world holds important consequences for investors, who can expect a world less globalised and more prone to conflict, with a growing state role in the economy. One clear consequence for investors is the significant inflationary pressures of this new world, as regional powers emphasise national strategic interests and self-sufficiency. As the US’s power ebbs and the US dollar’s importance as a reserve currency declines, building robust and diversified multi-asset portfolios is more important than ever to achieving long-term investment goals.

title: Exportaciones de México a EU, con impacto negativo por aranceles de Trump
content: Aunque el país se mantiene como principal socio comercial del vecino país, las ventas de productos como hortalizas, frutas, cárnicos, cervezas, tequila, autos, acero y aluminio han bajado sus ventas ...
resumen: En los primeros cuatro meses del 2025, se ha registrado un descenso en la participación de los productos “Hechos en México” en el mercado de importaciones de EU, derivado principalmente por la imposición de aranceles a productos como hortalizas, frutas, carnes, cervezas y tequilas, acero y aluminio, lo que ha encarecido el precio de los autos. En los cinco meses del gobierno del republicano Donald Trump, las ventas de productos mexicanos con destino a EU han visto un freno debido a gravámenes ordenados por el magnate neoyorquino, bajo el argumento de seguridad nacional y a supuestos abusos por parte de países con los que hay intercambios comerciales. La Secretaría de Economía señaló en abril pasado que se esperaba un mayor impacto en la caída de las exportaciones, pero se han mantenido las ventas hacia EU. El titular de Economía, Marcelo Ebrard, subrayó que se trabaja en varias acciones y estrategias para mitigar el impacto de la disminución en las exportaciones, como la diversificación de mercados y fortalecer la competitividad de las empresas mexicanas. Se busca aprovechar al máximo el Tratado de Libre Comercio entre México, Estados Unidos y Canadá (T-MEC), y entre las prioridades está impulsar el consumo nacional para compensar la disminución de las exportaciones al vecino país, que es el principal socio comercial y comprador de los productos mexicanos. México registró en abril pasado una caída interanual del 2.7% en sus exportaciones, que ahora suman 41,869 millones de dólares, frente a un incremento global en las importaciones estadounidenses del 1.9%, alcanzando los 276,086 millones de dólares. Las exportaciones de China y Canadá también cayeron en un 19.7% y 14.4%, respectivamente, debido a los gravámenes impuestos por el gobierno de Donald Trump. En el primer cuatrimestre del año, las ventas de hortalizas y frutas de México a EU disminuyeron en volumen en 2025, con una caída del 2.1%. Las exportaciones agroalimentarias mexicanas al vecino país alcanzaron los 9 mil 282 millones de dólares en el primer trimestre de 2025, lo que representa un aumento del 2.1% con respecto al mismo período de 2024. El aguacate, uno de los productos mexicanos más anhelados por los consumidores de EU redujo su volumen de exportación este 2025. De acuerdo con el Departamento de Agricultura de Estados Unidos, las exportaciones del fruto mexicano alcanzaron los 4,000 millones de dólares, aunque la cantidad enviada para el Super Tazón fue menor que la del 2024. En los primeros meses de 2025, las ventas de reses a EU cayeron un 60%, pasando de 485 mil bovinos exportados en el mismo periodo de 2024 a 195 mil en 2025, lo que ha provocado pérdidas millonarias para los ganaderos mexicanos, ya que se estiman pérdidas diarias por 11.4 millones de dólares. En 2024 se exportaron 400.3 millones de litros de tequila, de los que el 84 por ciento fue comprado por el vecino país. El Consejo Regulador del Tequila, A.C. (CRT), advierte que busca nuevas estrategias para no afectar el precio que llega a su consumidor. La agencia Reuters estimó que unos 3 mil millones de dólares en importaciones de tequila y mezcal están en riesgo debido a los aranceles. La cerveza también se ha visto afectada su exportación debido a los aranceles, con una caída del 2.7% en abril pasado. Los envíos de acero disminuyeron un 63.1% en comparación con el mismo período del 2024. Aunque las exportaciones de acero, aluminio y sus manufacturas de México a EU fueron de 16,000 millones de dólares el año pasado, el 82% se dirigió a Estados Unidos, lo que representa el 2.1% de las exportaciones totales de México. En mayo pasado se ensamblaron 358,209 autos ligeros, una baja de 2% interanual, mientras que las exportaciones retrocedieron 2.9%, con 301,112 unidades enviadas al extranjero, principalmente al mercado estadounidense.

content: El ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, Rubén Ramírez Lezcano, se reunió por segundo día consecutivo con parlamentarios de diferentes partidos en Washington, Estados Unidos. Los congresistas manifestaro ...
resumen: El ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, Rubén Ramírez Lezcano, se reunió por segundo día consecutivo con parlamentarios de diferentes partidos en Washington, Estados Unidos. Los congresistas manifestaron interés en visitar Paraguay. La reunión sirvió para conversar sobre la relación bilateral y las oportunidades de trabajar juntos en la región. Durante los encuentros, los parlamentarios manifestaron su deseo de visitar el Paraguay y remarcaron que es un aliado importante para los EE.UU. Se mostraron interesados en conocer la energía limpia y renovable que produce el Paraguay, así como el clima de negocios. Destacaron el nivel de crecimiento que marcan los indicadores internacionales. El senador republicano, Bernie Moreno, indicó que podría estar en Paraguay antes de que termine el año, en tanto que el senador demócrata, Tim Kaine señaló que estará en Asunción en breve. Ambos legisladores coincidieron en señalar que los EE.UU. debe intensificar su relación con el Paraguay. El canciller también se reunió con los congresistas Adriano Espaillat, del Partido Demócrata, y con Glenn Thompson del Partido Republicano, presidente de la Comisión de Agricultura quien se interesó por la producción de alimentos.

title: Trump May Levy 10% Tariff on All Imports, 20% on China: Jefferies
content: Jefferies warns that Donald Trump may introduce a 10% tariff on all U.S. imports and 20% on Chinese goods if re-elected. Jefferies outlines what this means for inflation, trade, and market volatility.
resumen: Jefferies warns that Donald Trump may introduce a 10% tariff on all U.S. imports and 20% on Chinese goods if re-elected. The report indicates Trump would impose a level 10% tariff across all imports and a 20% tariff particularly on Chinese products, marking a strategic move in the U.S.'s trade stance before the 2026 election cycle. Jefferies is proposing that Trump wants an "off-ramp" from the chaotic tariff hikes of his previous presidency. "Tariffs will end up at a global 10% across the board, and 20% for China, with the 10% tariff residual from the initial Trump administration," the report said. China has unilaterally rolled out economic counter-repression. The report identifies Beijing's move to harness its monopoly over rare earth elements, tying exports to Washington's denial of Chinese access to cutting-edge semiconductors. China's gold imports in April 2025 climbed 73% from the previous month to a 11-month high of 127.5 tonnes. Chinese gold ETFs have already gained 82.1 tonnes in 2025—already more than last year's 53.3 tonnes—according to the World Gold Council. To go after a hypothetical deal with China, the report states, Trump would have to break with the national security lobby, which has continued to support tough trade measures. "Trump will have to break with the national security lobby, particularly with China's intelligent move to connect the rare earth issue," the brokerage stated. A 10% across-the-board tariff is easy to administer, but a 20% tariff on China maintains the combative bite.

title: Cockpit Cold War: How U.S.-E.U. Tensions Are Scrambling the Future of Avionics
content: In the high-stakes arena of international diplomacy, tariffs and trade threats rarely remain confined to spreadsheets and customs booths. This year, when […] ...
resumen: In the high-stakes arena of international diplomacy, tariffs and trade threats rarely remain confined to spreadsheets and customs booths. This year, when President Donald Trump threatened fresh tariffs on European Union exports, much of the media attention focused on agriculture, luxury goods, and cars. But quietly, and with potentially long-lasting consequences, these tensions are rattling one of the most sensitive corners of the aerospace industry: avionics. The avionics industry has become one of the most intricate and globally interconnected sectors in aviation. Unlike engines or airframes, where a handful of dominant players control the space, avionics rely on a dense network of multinational partnerships, cross-licensing agreements, and real-time technological co-development. Many avionics suppliers are smaller-cap tech companies that don’t have brand name recognition. Now, with the reemergence of protectionist rhetoric, particularly from the Trump regime, the risk of economic nationalism interfering with avionics development is no longer theoretical. The E.U. and the U.S. are historically interdependent when it comes to building cockpits. Consider that Thales, the French electronics giant, supplies cockpit displays to Boeing, while Honeywell and Collins Aerospace—U.S. titans—power major Airbus systems. The very nature of avionics collaboration is rooted in decades of transatlantic engineering trust and shared standards. Disrupt that flow, and the consequences ripple far beyond supply chains. As tariffs materialize and bilateral tensions escalate into regulatory divergence, the cockpit could become collateral damage in a trade war that neither side can afford. European manufacturers might be pressured to localize supply chains or pivot toward domestic partners to mitigate tariff risks. That could mean Thales or Leonardo pushing to reduce their dependency on U.S. chips or software modules. Likewise, American giants like Honeywell might see increasing pressure from Washington to “buy American” and recalibrate avionics development away from European integration. But that would be both costly and regressive. Modern cockpits, especially in next-gen aircraft like the Airbus A321XLR or Boeing’s 777X, are not simple plug-and-play consoles. They are the result of years of international Research and Development (R&D), where flight management systems must conform to requirements from both the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA). The widening gulf between U.S. and E.U. regulatory frameworks, driven by a more protectionist trade posture, complicates dual certification and leads to longer lead times, higher costs, and ultimately, lower safety margins. In aviation, delays are not just about time. They’re about trust. There’s also the real possibility that retaliatory tariffs from Brussels could make U.S. avionics less competitive globally. If European OEMs—especially Airbus, ATR, or even the rising COMAC partners in China—find it costlier to procure American avionics, they may seek alternatives from European or Asian suppliers. Trump’s shattering of transatlantic cooperation has already frayed nerves in aerospace circles. For avionics, which now represent a growing share of aircraft value (sometimes up to 30% in military platforms), that’s a ticking time bomb. Avionics innovation also depends heavily on seamless data flow and joint research. Programs like Single European Sky ATM Research (SESAR) in Europe and NextGen in the U.S. are designed to modernize air traffic control and cockpit integration. These initiatives rely on data harmonization, synchronized upgrade cycles, and common interoperability standards. If geopolitics splinters these efforts into region-specific silos, the world could face a divided sky, where aircraft optimized for U.S. or E.U. airspace become less efficient or even incompatible when flying transcontinental routes. The effect on military avionics is poised to be even more profound. NATO allies have traditionally shared electronic systems for fighter jets, drones, and surveillance aircraft. If Trump’s America First doctrine makes it harder to export sensitive avionics tech to European partners or imposes bureaucratic hurdles, joint defense programs could splinter. That would undermine collective security while opening a window for China or Russia to deepen their own bilateral military tech ties in areas where the West should dominate. Unlike fuselage makers or engine OEMs, avionics companies operate in an environment of razor-thin margins and long development timelines. Uncertainty around tariffs or cross-border licensing raises their risk profiles and deflates corporate valuations, especially for firms with high European exposure.

title: Pacific Ocean life at risk from noisy deep-sea mining
content: MEXICO CITY, SciDev.Net] Noise pollution from deep-sea mining carries an invisible risk for sea-life, warn researchers, urging greater transparency from the industry to help mitigate the harms. Noise ...
resumen: Noise pollution from deep-sea mining carries an invisible risk for sea-life. Noise in the deep ocean can lead to a cascade of ecological consequences, altering biodiversity and the behaviours and physiology of many species. This could impact a food chain and ecosystem relied upon by Latin American coastal communities, according to marine experts. An analysis of more than 2,800 investigations conducted in the Clarion-Clipperton zone (CCZ) — a vast underwater plain twice the size of India located in the Pacific Ocean between Hawaii and Mexico — revealed that most of the types of animals that inhabit it are sensitive to sound. Much of marine life, including invertebrates, fish, and mammals, rely on sound for communication, navigation, and predator avoidance. The effects of noise pollution have only been studied in 35 per cent of species. Researchers say more data sharing is needed to understand the true impacts. 37 countries launched the first ever global political coalition to reduce harmful underwater noise pollution at the UN Ocean Conference in Nice, southern France. The High Ambition Coalition for a Quiet Ocean commits to support policies that promote quieter ship design, establish marine protected areas, and support capacity-building to assess and reduce ocean noise. UN Secretary-General António Guterres warned that unregulated deep-sea mining could turn the ocean into a lawless “Wild West”. The CCZ is the world’s largest mineral exploration region, full of mineral-rich deposits of cobalt, nickel, manganese and rare earths. According to the study, up to one third of fish species in the CCZ may be soniferous, meaning they produce or carry sound. Noise pollution can lead to changes in the physiology and behaviour of such species. Around three quarters of the publications reviewed in the study focused on mammalian and fish species. Invertebrates are massively underrepresented. A lack of transparency from mining companies also means that data on noise is lacking. The sound waves could affect migratory species, regional food chains and ecosystems that have ecological connections with the coasts of Latin America. The International Seabed Authority has granted 31 exploration licenses — 17 of them in the CCZ — and is under pressure to approve a code that would allow commercial exploitation. More than 30 countries, including several in Latin America, oppose this extractive activity and call for a moratorium, according to the Deep Sea Conservation Coalition. US President Donald Trump issued an executive order for the country to advance the exploitation of minerals in international waters.

resumen: En el peor momento de las relaciones de México y Estados Unidos, la Presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum se reunirá personalmente con su homólogo de ese país, Donald Trump, en el marco de la Cumbre del G7 que inicia este domingo en Kananaskis, provincia de Alberta, a la que asistirá por invitación del Primer Ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney. Luego de siete conversaciones telefónicas, será el primer encuentro desde la imposición del republicano de aranceles a remesas de ese país, aprobada por la Cámara de Representantes y pendiente de ratificación senatorial, que además tras una serie de redadas, originara violentas protestas en Los Ángeles el pasado fin de semana, extendida hoy a varias importantes ciudades de ese país, de lo que la Secretaria de Seguridad, Kristi Noem acusara a la Presidenta Sheinbaum de “alentarlas”, lo que ella rechazó de inmediato. Al mismo tiempo que el gobernador republicano de Texas, Greg Abbott, ordenó desplegar cinco mil elementos de la Guardia Nacional y más de dos mil policías en ese estado para frenar protestas de migrantes como en Los Ángeles, Chicago, Nueva York y otras ciudades, el gobierno de Estados Unidos ordenó a medio millón de migrantes, admitidos en el programa de permiso humanitario “CHNV” en el gobierno de Joe Biden, abandonar ese país. title: Boeing shares sink, dollar dives on Trump’s new trade threat
content: Wall Street stocks dipped early Thursday after fresh trade war rhetoric from President Donald Trump, while Boeing shares tumbled following a brutal Air ...
resumen:
Wall Street stocks dipped early Thursday after fresh trade war rhetoric from President Donald Trump, while Boeing shares tumbled following a brutal Air India crash on a 787 jet.

Trump threatened to “send letters out” with an ultimatum to other trading partners.

Boeing shares shed about five percent after a London-bound 787 Dreamliner crashed in western India, likely killing all 242 people on board.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.4 percent at 42,705.52. The S&P 500 slipped 0.1 percent to 6,018.24, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index also declined 0.1 percent to 19,595.85.

Wholesale prices rose 0.1 percent last month.

Oracle surged 12.1 percent following an upbeat earnings report. The software giant scored eight percent revenue growth in the last year.

The dollar plunged on Thursday after US President Donald Trump threatened higher unilateral tariffs on trade partners, and oil see-sawed as traders evaluated the probability behind reports that Israel could be gearing up to strike Iran.

Boeing’s share price slumped sharply in the wake of a deadly 787 Dreamliner crash in India.

The blue-chip Dow struggled in the red.

All European stock markets finished lower, except London.

The dollar was down against the euro, and at one point fell by more than one percent to its lowest point in three years against the European single currency.

Trump has rattled markets with fresh threats of unilateral tariff rates on several trading partners.

Trump on Wednesday said he would be sending letters within the next two weeks to other countries’ governments to announce unilateral US levies on their exports to America.

The European Union is staring down the barrel of 50-percent tariffs -- at least -- when a pause on them ends on July 9.

The EU has reportedly drawn up plans to slap 100 billion euros ($116 billion) of additional tariffs on US goods if the US levies go ahead.

The indices that seem most exposed to tariffs are China, Mexico, the UK, and those of commodity exporters like South Africa, Saudi Arabia, Australia, and especially Canada.

Markets were also following reports that Israel was poised to launch airstrikes on Iran -- along with Trump saying he was now “less confident” that talks with Tehran would end up with it rolling back its nuclear programme.

Oil prices flipped direction for much Thursday.

In New York share trading, Boeing dropped more than five percent after a London-bound Air India plane -- a Boeing 787 -- carrying 242 people had crashed in Ahmedabad.

The US planemaker declared itself ready to support Air India following the crash, the first involving a 787 Dreamliner.

resumen: Un grupo de clientes del Canal Mayorista de CMI|Molinos Modernos visitó la sede central de Corporación Multi Inversiones (CMI) en Guatemala. La iniciativa busca reforzar las relaciones comerciales y consolidar la visión de liderazgo regional del grupo empresarial. Los participantes conocieron la historia centenaria de CMI, sus pilares de cultura empresarial —bajo el concepto Somos CMI—, y los principales proyectos de valor compartido que desarrolla la corporación en Latinoamérica. La visita incluyó una rueda de negocios encabezada por Eduardo Romero, director general de la Unidad de Negocio B4C. Krist Núñez, director Comercial Caribe, expresó que la visita es una manera de agradecer la confianza que los clientes depositan en CMI y que reforzar estos vínculos es clave para construir relaciones sostenibles a largo plazo. El programa contempló visitas guiadas a sitios emblemáticos de Guatemala, como las ruinas arqueológicas de Iximché en Tecpán y los pueblos de San Juan y Santiago, en el Lago de Atitlán. CMI cuenta con dos grandes agrupaciones de negocio: CMI Alimentos y CMI Capital. En República Dominicana, CMI Alimentos opera mediante Molinos Modernos y Molinos del Ozama, responsables de marcas como Galletas Hatuey, Guarina, Dino, Pastas Milano y Harina Blanquita. CMI Capital gestiona la planta de energía solar Mata de Palma, ubicada en Guerra, con una capacidad instalada de 52 megavatios de energía renovable. CMI reafirma su compromiso con la creación de oportunidades que impacten positivamente en las comunidades donde opera. Corporación Multi Inversiones (CMI) es una empresa familiar multilatina con 105 años de historia, más de 40 mil colaboradores y presencia en más de 16 países de América Latina y Estados Unidos.

title: Trump advierte que Irán "debe llegar" a un acuerdo sobre su programa nuclear tras ataques de Israel
content: Israel lanzó ataques contra Irán el viernes y afirmó que había atacado instalaciones nucleares, fábricas de misiles balísticos y comandantes militares.
resumen: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, instó a Teherán a llegar a un acuerdo sobre su programa nuclear tras los ataques de Israel sobre territorio iraní. Trump dijo: “Ya ha habido una gran muerte y destrucción, pero todavía hay tiempo para hacer que esta masacre, con los próximos ataques ya planeados siendo aún más brutales, llegue a su fin. Irán debe llegar a un acuerdo, antes de que no quede nada, y salvar lo que una vez fue conocido como el Imperio Iraní. No más muerte, no más destrucción, solo háganlo, antes de que sea demasiado tarde”. Trump también mencionó que algunos de los altos mandos iraníes, que han muerto en los ataques de Israel, a los que definió como de “la línea dura”, hablaron en su momento con “valentía” sobre el acuerdo “pero no sabían lo que estaba a punto de suceder”. Trump afirmó: “Le di a Irán oportunidad tras oportunidad para llegar a un acuerdo. Les dije, en las palabras más fuertes, que ‘simplemente lo hicieran’, pero no importaba cuánto lo intentaran, no importaba lo cerca que estuvieran, simplemente no podían hacerlo”. Trump también expresó que advirtió que lo que venía para Irán “sería mucho peor que cualquier cosa que sepan, anticipen o les hayan dicho, que los Estados Unidos fabrican el mejor y más letal equipo militar en cualquier parte del mundo, por mucho, y que Israel tiene mucho, con mucho más por venir y saben cómo usarlo”. Trump calificó el ataque israelí contra Irán como "excelente”. Israel lanzó ataques contra Irán el viernes y afirmó que había atacado instalaciones nucleares, fábricas de misiles balísticos y comandantes militares. Al menos 20 altos comandantes iraníes, incluido el jefe de la Guardia Revolucionaria, Hosein Salami, y el comandante de la Fuerza Aeroespacial, Amir Ali Hajizadeh, murieron en los ataques de Israel contra Irán el viernes, informaron a Reuters dos fuentes regionales.
