title: Who's really bleeding in the US-China tariff war?
content: Washington and Beijing strike a fragile truce in London, easing rare earth curbs and export controls—but with limits in place, global trade stability remains uncertain.
resumen:
Washington and Beijing struck a fragile truce in London, easing rare earth curbs and export controls.

President Donald Trump announced that a new trade deal with China is “done.”

The provisional agreement outlines a significant concession: China will resume full exports of rare earth minerals and magnets to the United States.

In return, the United States is expected to ease restrictions on certain industrial exports to China, including commercial jet engines, ethane, and specialised manufacturing components. However, restrictions on advanced semiconductor technologies will remain largely unchanged.

China is imposing a six-month limit on rare-earth export licenses issued to US companies.

The US auto industry was approaching a production standstill after China halted shipments of critical magnets used in electric motors, windshields, and vehicle doors.

China is responsible for over 70% of global rare earth processing.

Export licenses—suspended by Beijing in April amid rising tensions—will now be temporarily restored for six months.

President Trump confirmed the development in a post on his Truth Social platform on June 11.

The "55% tariffs" figure cited by Trump is understood to reflect a combination of levies: the 10% global baseline tariff implemented under his administration, a pre-existing 25% tariff on Chinese industrial goods first imposed in 2020, and a more recent 20% tariff targeting imports linked to fentanyl trafficking.

China has reportedly agreed to impose a 10% flat tariff on US goods entering its market.

The US President also posted on Truth Social, “Adding to the China readout, President XI and I are going to work closely together to open up China to American Trade. This would be a great WIN for both countries!!!”

The six-month license limit and selective relaxation of trade restrictions underscore the deal’s fragility.

Washington had stepped up visa denials for students pursuing degrees in science, engineering, and AI-related fields, particularly those linked to Chinese state institutions or the Communist Party.

April’s export ban on rare earth magnets from China—used in EVs, missiles, wind turbines, and jet engines—exposed how vulnerable US industries remain despite efforts to diversify.

The London agreement restores access for now, but only under six-month licenses.

Washington has agreed to relax select industrial export restrictions—covering jet engines, ethane, and some manufacturing inputs.

Semiconductor tools, chip design software, and high-performance computing components remain tightly controlled.

COMAC’s C919 jetliner, aimed at challenging Boeing and Airbus, remains stalled by these controls—its supply chain still reliant on US and European firms like GE and Honeywell.

COMAC’s C919 uses an engine developed by CFM International, a joint venture between US-based GE Aerospace and France’s Safran.

The US and its allies continue to block China’s access to critical chipmaking gear.

Beijing has poured state funds into building domestic capacity.

China still depends on Western tools to produce advanced chips used in AI, military tech, and cloud computing.

The US is now reportedly moving to further restrict Chinese access to memory technologies like High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) and Dynamic Random-Access Memory (DRAM), while blacklisting companies suspected of bypassing controls through third countries.

China’s overall exports rose 4.8% in May 2025, but exports to the US fell nearly 10%, while Chinese imports from the US dropped 7.4%.

China’s trade surplus with the US to $103.2 billion.

South Korean exports surged 5.4% year-on-year in the first ten days of June to $15.48 billion.

Semiconductor exports alone jumped 22%.

Vehicle shipments also rose 8.4%, while exports to the US and EU grew 3.9% and 14.5%, respectively.

Exports to China increased by 2.9%.

Imports jumped by 11.5%, widening the trade deficit to $1.78 billion.

Vietnam’s trade surplus with the US surged to $12.2 billion, a 42% year-on-year increase, with exports hitting a post-pandemic high of $13.8 billion in May 2025.

Vietnam’s imports from China rose 21%.

A looming 46% “reciprocal” tariff proposed by President Trump.

The recent US-China trade agreement may ease some pressure on trans-Pacific air cargo routes.

The six-month limit on China’s rare earth export licenses, unresolved semiconductor restrictions, and conditional access for Chinese students reflect ongoing mistrust.

content: El Ministerio de Comercio de China confirma que autorizó solicitudes de exportación de tierras raras, mientras Trump celebra una tregua comercial que abarca también semiconductores y estudiantes chino ...
resumen:
El Ministerio de Comercio de China confirmó que autorizó solicitudes de exportación de tierras raras.
Trump celebró el pacto como una victoria económica y estratégica.
China anunció la aprobación de un número no revelado de licencias para la exportación de tierras raras, luego de un acuerdo alcanzado con Estados Unidos que incluye el envío adelantado de estos minerales.
Las tierras raras son fundamentales para la producción de vehículos eléctricos, semiconductores y sistemas de defensa.
Pekín se comprometió a suministrar “imanes completos y cualquier tierra rara necesaria” como parte de un nuevo entendimiento, pendiente de aprobación final por el propio líder chino, Xi Jinping.
China había impuesto restricciones estrictas al comercio exterior de tierras raras desde abril, con lo que obligó a las empresas a solicitar licencias de exportación.
Pekín busca normalizar el comercio bilateral sin ceder el control total sobre un recurso que domina con más del 60 % de la producción global.
El portavoz del Ministerio de Comercio, He Yadong, señaló que el país asiático revisa cuidadosamente las solicitudes “con base en la normativa vigente y tomando en cuenta las preocupaciones legítimas de los países importadores”.
Las nuevas licencias tendrán una vigencia de seis meses.
La administración Trump ofreció permitir que estudiantes chinos continúen accediendo a universidades estadounidenses, a cambio del envío anticipado de estos minerales.

title: Tánaiste told Trump trade representative tariffs ‘threaten’ US-Ireland relationship
content: The European Commission is preparing to navigate another round of trade talks with President Trump’s administration. Last week, the EU threatened to speed up retaliatory measures against the US if ...
resumen:
Tánaiste Simon Harris met with US trade representative Jamieson Greer to discuss ending trade dispute.
The meeting between the pair on Thursday was described as “positive” and “constructive” by the Irish side.
Simon Harris said he outlined to Mr Greer the “hugely successful two-way economic relationship between the US and Ireland”.
Mr. Harris said tariffs “threaten” relations between the US and Ireland and are bad for business, bad for consumers and bad for workers on both side of the Atlantic.
The Tánaiste said he assured Mr Greer of Ireland’s “commitment to supporting a mutually beneficial agreement that works for the US and the EU”.
He welcomed Mr Greer’s positive meeting with European commissioner for trade and economic security, Maroš Šefčovič, in Paris last week.
In late May, Mr Trump expressed frustration with the pace of talks and threatened to raise the tariff rate to 50 per cent, although he later said he would hold off on the threat until July 9th.
The EU had been slated for a 20 per cent tariff under the reciprocal rates announced by US president Donald Trump in April.
A temporary pause took the rate down to 10 per cent through July 8th.
Thursday’s discussion followed on from a meeting between Mr Harris and US commerce secretary Howard Lutnick in Washington in April.
The two politicians on Thursday “discussed recent trade developments, including a constructive exchange of views on the ongoing negotiations between the US and EU.”
After the meeting with Mr Šefčovič, Mr Greer said the EU had provided the US with “a credible starting point for discussions on reciprocal trade” and the discussion showed Washington “a willingness by the EU to work with us to find a concrete way forward to achieve reciprocal trade”.
The European Commission is preparing to navigate another round of trade talks with Mr Trump’s administration.
The Irish Government has been lobbying the European Commission to try to keep important domestic sectors like aviation, medtech, agricultural feed and whiskey out of the transatlantic trade war.

title: Barclays cambia perspectiva de aeropuertos europeos: sube ADP y Zúrich, baja Aena
content: Investing.com - Los analistas de Barclays (LON:BARC) han revisado su perspectiva sobre los operadores aeroportuarios europeos, mejorando Aéroports de París (EPA:ADP) (ADP) y Aeropuerto de Zúrich a "ov ...
resumen:
Los analistas de Barclays han revisado su perspectiva sobre los operadores aeroportuarios europeos, mejorando Aéroports de París (ADP) y Aeropuerto de Zúrich a "overweight" desde "equal weight", mientras rebajaron Aena y Aeropuerto Internacional de Atenas (AIA) a "equal weight" desde "overweight". La correduría mantuvo su calificación "overweight" para Fraport.

La mejora de ADP sigue a señales regulatorias positivas y un reenfoque estratégico en sus activos de París. Barclays indicó que la inestabilidad política persiste, pero la propiedad estatal podría proteger a ADP de cargas financieras adicionales. El reciente cambio legal del gobierno que permite revisiones regulatorias de 10 años y reduce disputas sobre el costo promedio ponderado de capital fueron citados como señales de progreso. La estimación de EBITDA para ADP en el año fiscal 2026 aumentó un 2%, y el precio objetivo subió de €103 a €125.

La mejora del Aeropuerto de Zúrich refleja un camino más visible para su proyecto Noida en India y plazos regulatorios más claros. Barclays espera que las tarifas aeroportuarias y operaciones sean confirmadas a fin de año. El EBITDA del año fiscal 2026 se revisó al alza en un 4%, con un precio objetivo que aumentó de CHF212 a CHF255. La correduría señaló que las ganancias recientes de acciones no compensan completamente el potencial de los próximos catalizadores.

Aena fue rebajada debido a su valoración, con la acción cotizando cerca del precio objetivo revisado de €238, ligeramente por debajo de €240. Barclays mantuvo sin cambios las estimaciones de ganancias pero señaló el alto gasto de capital (capex) por la expansión del Aeropuerto de Barcelona. Los riesgos regulatorios fueron minimizados, con analistas esperando tarifas aeroportuarias estables en el próximo período regulatorio. El EBITDA para el año fiscal 2026 se pronosticó en €3.98 mil millones, en línea con el consenso.

El Aeropuerto Internacional de Atenas también vio una rebaja, con la acción cerca del precio objetivo actualizado de Barclays de €10.25. La correduría destacó el fuerte turismo entrante y una temporada turística extendida en Grecia, pero indicó que estos aspectos positivos ya están reflejados en el precio. El EBITDA del año fiscal 2026 se mantuvo sin cambios. Barclays citó un margen limitado para mayores dividendos o nuevos catalizadores de crecimiento bajo la estructura actual de concesión.

Fraport mantuvo su calificación OW, respaldada por la próxima apertura de la Terminal Tres en Frankfurt en 2026, que se espera mejore los ingresos comerciales y la experiencia de los pasajeros. Barclays proyecta que la compañía pasará de un flujo de caja libre en equilibrio en 2025 a positivo en 2026 a medida que disminuya el capex en Frankfurt y Lima. El precio objetivo de €72 y las estimaciones de ganancias de la correduría se mantuvieron sin cambios.

Las tendencias de tráfico mostraron un desempeño mixto en el primer trimestre, con un crecimiento de pasajeros rezagado respecto a la capacidad de asientos, en parte debido al calendario de Semana Santa. Las rutas de larga distancia hacia Medio Oriente y Asia están creciendo más rápido que los mercados intraeuropeos y atlánticos, lo que Barclays considera favorable para los ingresos minoristas por pasajero. Las presiones inflacionarias en los costos están disminuyendo.

title: Cost of President Trump’s tariffs hits home, as several consumer goods and services surge to record highs
content: The Tribune is tracking 11 everyday costs for Americans — eggs, milk, bread, bananas, oranges, tomatoes, chicken, ground beef, gasoline, electricity and natural gas — and how they are changing, or ...
resumen:
The cost of bananas, ground beef, and electricity have surged to record highs. The cost of a handful of everyday goods and services has increased by 5% to 10% since Trump took office.

The average nationwide cost of bread, milk, and tomatoes has dropped since December. The price of chicken and oranges has stayed much the same.

The Tribune is tracking 11 everyday costs: eggs, milk, bread, bananas, oranges, tomatoes, chicken, ground beef, gasoline, electricity, and natural gas. This tracker is updated monthly using CPI data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.

*   **Eggs:** The average cost of a dozen large Grade A eggs is $4.55 nationwide, about 9.6% higher than before Trump took office.
*   **Milk:** A gallon of fresh, fortified whole milk costs about $4.02. Prices are up more than 4% year-over-year.
*   **Bread:** White bread costs $1.88 per pound.
*   **Bananas:** Bananas cost a record-breaking $0.66 per pound.
*   **Oranges:** The average price per pound for navel oranges is $1.56 nationwide. Orange prices are up 5% from the previous month.
*   **Tomatoes:** The average price of field-grown tomatoes was approximately $1.71 per pound, down roughly 17% since Trump took power. Prices are down a little more than 8% from this time last year.
*   **Chicken:** Chicken is $2.06 per pound.
*   **Ground Beef:** The average price of 100% ground beef chuck is now $6.02 per pound.
*   **Electricity:** The average price of electricity nationwide was 18 cents per kilowatt-hour, the highest on record.
*   **Gasoline:** Gasoline costs about 5% more than it did during the last month of the administration of President Joe Biden. At $3.31 per gallon of regular unleaded. Year-over-year, prices have declined by roughly 12%. In Chicago, gas is about 11 cents higher than the nationwide average, sitting at $3.42 per gallon.
*   **Natural Gas:** Natural gas averaged $1.63 per therm, up nearly 7% under the Trump administration.

title: Fitch Ratings ajustó a la baja proyección de crecimiento mundial; perspectiva de bonos soberanos se deterioró
content: La firma dijo en su informe de Perspectivas de los soberanos globales que los soberanos globales están atravesando condiciones macrocrediticias más desafiantes.
resumen:
Fitch Ratings ajustó su pronóstico de crecimiento económico global desde el 2,2 % hasta el 2 % para este año.

La firma atribuyó este resultado al aumento de los aranceles comerciales y a la incertidumbre sobre las políticas económicas de EE. UU.

Esto los llevó a revisar la perspectiva de los bonos soberanos globales para 2025 de ‘neutral’ a ‘deterioro’.

Las perspectivas de calificación están cerca de estar balanceadas, con 13 mercados en perspectiva positiva, y 10 en perspectiva negativa.

title: El FMI ve «sorpresas positivas» para las economías emergentes en el primer trimestre de 2025
content: El Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) dijo que ha visto "sorpresas positivas" para las economías emergentes en el primer trimestre de 2025.
resumen:
El Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) dijo este jueves que ha visto «sorpresas positivas» para el crecimiento de las economías emergentes y en desarrollo en los tres primeros meses del año, relacionadas con las rebajas y pausas en la guerra arancelaria impulsada por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, que podrían influir en una revisión al alza de las proyecciones de desaceleración para 2025.

La portavoz del FMI, Julie Kozack, respondió que han observado algunas sorpresas positivas en el crecimiento del primer trimestre para este grupo de países, incluyendo a China. También han visto reducciones recientes en algunos aranceles, lo que representa un riesgo al alza para su pronóstico.

En abril, el organismo recortó medio punto en su previsión de crecimiento económico global hasta el 2,8 % debido a los efectos de la política de gravámenes impulsada por Trump y una caída para los mercados emergentes y en desarrollo, del 4,3 % en 2024 hasta el 3,7 % este año.

Desde entonces, las pausas en la aplicación de los aranceles por Washington y los acuerdos logrados con Reino Unido y China, han modificado el panorama económico, algo que el FMI tomará en cuenta para la revisión de sus proyecciones, cuya publicación está prevista para fines de julio próximo.

Ante lo que el organismo califica como «un panorama económico complejo y de incertidumbre» para las economías emergentes y en desarrollo, el FMI recomienda una «una respuesta política multifacética».

El FMI recomienda calibrar cuidadosamente la política monetaria y las políticas macroprudenciales o prudenciales para mantener la estabilidad en los países. También recomienda a este grupo de países reconstruir los márgenes de maniobra fiscales.

La portavoz también recordó que han alentado a los países «a emprender las reformas necesarias para no retrasar más las reformas asociadas con el impulso a la productividad y el crecimiento a largo plazo».

El FMI lleva tiempo hablando de un entorno de bajo crecimiento y alto endeudamiento, y esto, por supuesto, también aplica a este grupo de países. Por lo tanto, abordar la deuda es importante, por supuesto, mediante la consolidación fiscal, pero también, y de forma muy importante, impulsar el crecimiento y el aumento de la productividad.

El FMI recortó en medio punto la previsión del crecimiento económico global para este año, hasta el 2,8 %, debido al efecto en todas las economías de la guerra arancelaria desatada por Trump, que según las previsiones, lastrará principalmente a Estados Unidos, China y México.

Específicamente para los mercados emergentes y las economías en desarrollo, el FMI prevé en sus estimados de abirl una caída respectiva de 0,5 y 0,4 puntos, hasta el 3,7 % y el 3,9 %, respectivamente, este año y el siguiente.

Para Latinoamérica y el Caribe se anticipa una rebaja respecto a enero de 0,5 puntos en 2025 (hasta el 2 %) y de 0,3 para 2026 (2,4 %).

title: Sheinbaum expresa rechazo a redadas contra personas que ‘trabajan honestamente en EE.UU.’
content: El encuentro se dio en plenas negociaciones por la imposición de aranceles al acero y aluminio por parte de Estados Unidos.
resumen:
La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, señaló este jueves, 12 de junio de 2025, que en su reunión con el subsecretario de Estado estadounidense, Christopher Landau, se reafirmó la voluntad de “buscar la mejor relación” bilateral en medio de la tensión por las protestas tras las redadas a migrantes. Además reiteró su rechazo porque persiguen a personas que “trabajan honestamente” en Estados Unidos.

Durante su conferencia de prensa matutina, Sheinbaum enfatizó que hablaron de la defensa de los migrantes, y que no estaban de acuerdo con que se utilizaran las redadas para detener a personas que trabajan honestamente en los Estados Unidos, ya que eso iba a dañar no solamente a las personas, sino a la propia economía de los Estados Unidos.

La gobernante mexicana puntualizó que durante el encuentro abordaron distintos temas, entre ellos, la seguridad, donde su gabinete le mostró los resultados obtenidos en los primeros meses de su Administración.

Sheinbaum refirió que el encuentro con Landau fue más de cortesía, ya que vino a presentarse en su nuevo encargo en el departamento de Estado del gobierno del presidente (Donald) Trump y, a buscar la mejor relación entre México y Estados Unidos, con quien también trató la próxima visita del secretario de Estado, Marco Rubio.

En la reunión, en la que también estuvo presente el nuevo embajador de Estados Unidos en México, Ronald Johnson, hablaron de la importancia de fortalecer la relación entre ambos países.

La reunión ocurre en medio de la tensión entre México y Estados Unidos debido a los recientes señalamientos de la secretaria de Seguridad Nacional estadounidense, Kristi Noem, quien acusó a Sheinbaum de incitar las protestas en Los Ángeles, algo rechazado como “absolutamente” falso por la mandataria.

El encuentro se dio en plenas negociaciones por la imposición de aranceles al acero y aluminio por parte de Estados Unidos, en las que México buscó quedar exento de estos gravámenes.

El ‘número dos’ de la diplomacia estadounidense se encuentra en una gira de trabajo entre el 10 y el 13 de junio en la que, además de México, visitará El Salvador y Guatemala.

De acuerdo a la nota oficial del Departamento de Estado, Landau, quien fue embajador en México entre 2019 y 2021, sostendrá conversaciones para promover el crecimiento económico a través del sector privado, fomentar inversiones comerciales de Estados Unidos en la región y subrayar la importancia de erradicar la migración ilegal.

title: Trump gets unexpected win in latest economic numbers
content: Steve Rattner, an economic analyst for MSNBC’s “Morning Joe,” explained Thursday that the latest numbers from the Labor Department showed unexpected good news for Trump. He said many analysts ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump’s economy defied some expectations in the latest economic report, said MSNBC’s top economic analyst.

Steve Rattner, an economic analyst for MSNBC’s “Morning Joe,” explained Thursday that the latest numbers from the Labor Department showed unexpected good news for Trump.

He said many analysts forecasted that Trump’s tariffs would drive up inflation, but that the latest numbers suggest that has not happened yet.

Prices for all goods went up by 2.4% in May while prices for core goods, which exclude energy and food prices, went up 2.8% last month.

Economists still expect them to rise by at least 3% by the end of the year.

The World Bank downgraded the U.S.’s growth estimates for the year.

The new estimates show the U.S. growing at about half of what it did last year under former President Joe Biden.

The World Bank had been projecting back in January, 2.3% now they’re down at 1.4%.

1.4% is exactly half of the 2.8% that was achieved in the last year of the Biden administration.

The cost of groceries, toys and games, and large appliances rose.

The price of new and used cars, clothes, airfares, and hotel rooms all dropped from April to May.

On a monthly basis, overall prices ticked up just 0.1% from April to May, down from 0.2% the previous month, with inflationary pressures appearing muted.

Core prices also dropped to 0.1% from 0.2%.

Many economists expect the import taxes to modestly increase inflation in the second half of the year.

Companies ranging from Walmart to Lululemon to J.M. Smucker have said they will raise prices in the coming months to offset the impact of tariffs.

title: US is more vulnerable to a trade war with EU than with China
content: Amid rising trade tension between historic allies, Trump has increased steel and aluminium tariffs on the EU. Trump, however, cannot treat the EU in the same way he treats China.
resumen: On June 4, 2025, Donald Trump doubled tariffs on EU steel and aluminium from 25% to 50% in an attempt to attain a ‘good quality’ trade proposal from the bloc. Trump threatened to impose a 50% baseline tariff on the EU, and some of the US’ closest strategic partners, in May. Trump has called the EU a “mini-China” in the past, citing the US trade deficit in goods, specifically in cars and agricultural goods, and impatience with ongoing negotiations as the reasons for such extreme ‘retaliatory’ measures. According to GlobalData TS Lombard, a 50% baseline tariff on the EU would wipe out an estimated 1.6% of EU GDP growth. With Eurozone growth figures for 2025 hovering between 0.2% and 0.5%, any increase in baseline tariff could result in recessionary pressures for Europe in the immediate future, with more exposed nations, like Ireland for instance, facing larger GDP shocks of up to 8%. The EU has drawn up an import duty list of $21bn (€18bn) of US goods. The EU can now either engage in a tit-for-tat trade war, similar to the Chinese approach, or, similar to the British approach, try to reach a deal with the Americans. The EU imported $370bn of US goods in 2024, exporting more than $600bn to the US in the same timeframe. China, a nation roughly three times the size of the EU, only imported $144bn from the US in 2024. Some 58% of the US’ white population, a segment of the population that voted in droves for Trump, considers themselves European in some kind of way, according to a 2020 census from the US Census Bureau. When it comes to services, the US has a sizeable trade surplus with the EU at around $109bn. The economic effects of US import restrictions will largely fall on US businesses and consumers, and while the EU will feel the effects of reduced US demand for EU goods, any additional tit-for-tat tariffs will result in further pain for citizens (and voters) in the bloc. Nations that source large shares of their imports (Ireland, Belgium, France, and the Netherlands, for instance) from the US will likely fall out with Brussels over any further damage to the economy. The ECB has cut the main rate from 2.25% to 2% in anticipation of said recessionary pressures from potential tariffs. GlobalData TS Lombard predicted back in early May 2025 that Trump would turn on the EU.

title: Trump y EEUU podrían cortar anticipadamente su tregua arancelaria con Perú: golpe rompería los US$760 millones, según Renta 4
content: La medida, que debía entrar en vigor recién el 9 de julio, pone en jaque a sectores clave del país. Dos motores centrales de la economía se encuentran en capilla ...
resumen: Un informe de Renta 4 detalla que la medida podría generar pérdidas de US$760 millones, aunque su efecto sería limitado gracias a la diversificación hacia mercados como China, que absorbe el 33,8% de las exportaciones. El próximo 9 de julio de 2025 podría marcar un punto de inflexión para las exportaciones peruanas hacia Estados Unidos, ya que está programada la entrada en vigor de un arancel recíproco por la administración del presidente Donald Trump. Las exportaciones peruanas hacia Estados Unidos representan solo el 12,7% del total. En 2024, las exportaciones peruanas hacia Estados Unidos representaron el 12,7% del total de los US$74.646 millones exportados globalmente, una caída considerable en comparación con el 18,3% registrado en 2013. En términos del Producto Bruto Interno (PBI), las exportaciones hacia Estados Unidos equivalen al 3%. David Lizama, jefe de Análisis y Estrategia de Renta 4, declaró a Infobae Perú que “el arancel del 10% no le moverá la aguja al Perú”, subrayando que el impacto sería limitado debido a la diversificación de los mercados de exportación del país, especialmente hacia China, que en 2024 absorbió el 33,8% de las exportaciones peruanas. El arancel del 10% podría generar una reducción del 8% en las exportaciones peruanas hacia Estados Unidos, lo que equivaldría a una pérdida estimada de US$760 millones. Entre los sectores más expuestos a la imposición del arancel destacan las prendas de vestir y textiles, con un 51% de dependencia del mercado estadounidense, seguidos por la minería no metálica (40%) y las agroindustrias (36%). En términos absolutos, las agroindustrias lideran las exportaciones a Estados Unidos con US$4.024 millones en 2024, mientras que la minería tradicional y las prendas de vestir alcanzaron US$2.108 millones y US$862 millones, respectivamente. Dentro del sector agroindustrial, las frutas representan el principal rubro, con US$2.580 millones, destacando los arándanos (48% del total de frutas exportadas) y las uvas (33%). Se proyecta que el tipo de cambio cierre 2025 entre 3,70 y 3,80 soles por dólar. En 2024, el país experimentó una recuperación sostenida del consumo e inversión privada, lo que contribuyó a un mayor dinamismo del PBI en el cuarto trimestre. El cobre, uno de los principales productos de exportación de Perú, enfrenta un año de volatilidad en 2025, con precios proyectados en US$9.383 por tonelada al cierre del año.

content: En mayo, las importaciones en varios de los puertos más concurridos de Estados Unidos cayeron drásticamente. Este fenómeno se produjo en respuesta a la imposición temporal de aranceles del 145% por pa ...
resumen:
En mayo, las importaciones en varios de los puertos más concurridos de Estados Unidos cayeron drásticamente. Este fenómeno se produjo en respuesta a la imposición temporal de aranceles del 145% por parte del presidente Donald Trump sobre numerosos productos provenientes de China. La caída en las importaciones es la más notable de los últimos tiempos.

China sigue siendo el principal proveedor de bienes que llegan a Estados Unidos por vía marítima. Los puertos de la Costa Oeste se vieron particularmente afectados. En California, los puertos de Long Beach y Los Ángeles experimentaron caídas del 20.9% y 8.5% respectivamente. Seattle disminuyó un 17.3% y Tacoma un sorprendente 39.4%.

En la Costa Este, el volumen de importaciones en el Puerto de Nueva York y Nueva Jersey cayó un 15.3%. Norfolk, en Virginia, y Wilmington, en Carolina del Norte, también registraron descensos significativos de 14.7% y 17.6%, respectivamente. Los puertos del Golfo de México como Houston y Mobile, Alabama, se redujeron un 3.4% y un 20.4%.

Este descenso generalizado en las importaciones desde China condujo a una caída interanual del 28.5% en mayo. Los datos provienen del proveedor de tecnología de la cadena de suministro Descartes Datamyne.

Un marco de acuerdo comercial fue anunciado, estableciendo aranceles sobre China al 30%, esperando aprobación final. Esta tasa del 30% se sumaría a los aranceles del 25% ya existentes del primer mandato de Trump, acumulando un total del 55% en aranceles para China.

Los importadores se encontraron apresurados para asegurar reservas para los envíos de China que habían quedado pausados, aprovechando la reducción temporal de los aranceles al 30%. El jefe del Puerto de Los Ángeles, el más grande del país, ha expresado que no anticipa una avalancha de carga, ya que estos aranceles del 30% aún representan costos bastante elevados para los importadores.

title: Trade War Impacts Keep Jobless Claims at 8-Month High
content: U.S. filings for jobless benefits were unchanged last week, remaining at the higher end of recent ranges as uncertainty over the impact of trade wars lingers. New applications for jobless benefits ...
resumen:
U.S. filings for jobless benefits were unchanged last week, remaining at the higher end of recent ranges as uncertainty over the impact of trade wars lingers.

New applications for jobless benefits numbered 248,000 for the week ending June 7, the Labor Department said Thursday. Analysts had forecast 244,000 new applications.

A week ago, there were 248,000 jobless claim applications, which was the most since early October.

Weekly applications for jobless benefits have mostly bounced around a historically healthy range between 200,000 and 250,000 since COVID-19 throttled the economy five years ago.

The past three weeks, layoffs have been at the higher end of that range.

“There are early warning signs in the labor market,” said Navy Federal Credit Union’s chief economist, Heather Long.

Many companies have either trimmed their sales and profit expectations for 2025 or not issued guidance at all, often citing President Donald Trump’s dizzying rollout of tariff announcements.

Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has said the potential for both higher unemployment and inflation are elevated.

In early May, the Federal Reserve held its benchmark lending rate at 4.3% for the third straight meeting after cutting it three times at the end of last year.

Last week, the Labor Department reported that U.S. employers slowed their hiring in May, but still added a solid 139,000 jobs despite uncertainty over Trump’s trade wars.

In a separate report last week, Labor reported that U.S. job openings rose unexpectedly in April, but other data suggested that Americans are less optimistic about the labor market.

The report showed that the number of Americans quitting their jobs fell, while layoffs ticked higher.

The government reported one job for every unemployed person. As recently as December 2022, there were two vacancies for every jobless American.

The government has estimated that the U.S. economy shrank at a 0.2 percent annual pace in the first quarter of 2025.

Trump is attempting to reshape the global economy by dramatically increasing import taxes to rejuvenate the U.S. manufacturing sector.

On Wednesday, Google confirmed that it had offered buyouts to another swath of its workforce in a fresh round of cost-cutting.

Other companies that have announced job cuts this year include Procter & Gamble, Workday, Dow, CNN, Starbucks, Southwest Airlines, Microsoft and Facebook parent company Meta.

The government’s report on Thursday also showed that the four-week average of jobless claims rose by 5,000 to 240,250.

The total number of Americans receiving unemployment benefits for the week of May 31 jumped by 54,000 to 1.96 million, the most since November of 2021.

title: How Global Governance Can Survive
content: Yet to truly turn the G-7 into a body that can sustain the rules-based order, its members need to bolster their ranks, streamline their procedures, and strengthen the group’s legitimacy in the eyes of ...
resumen:
The article "How Global Governance Can Survive" by Victor Cha, John Hamre, and G. John Ikenberry discusses the need for the G-7 to reform and strengthen its role in global governance. The authors argue that the G-7, consisting of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States, is the only institution capable of sustaining the rules-based order, especially with the decline of the UN Security Council's effectiveness due to geopolitical rivalries.

The authors propose several reforms:

*   **Expanding Membership:** Adding Australia and South Korea to the G-7 to better represent the Indo-Pacific region and balance the group's geographical configuration. They also suggest consolidating the EU's two seats into one and potentially adding Spain.
*   **Institutional Reform:** Establishing a consultative body (troika) to set G-7 meeting agendas, creating a permanent secretariat, and forming formal task forces to track commitments. They also suggest involving emerging and middle powers and countries in the global South through consultation channels.

The authors highlight that the G-7 needs to broaden its scope, enhance its capabilities, and add new voices to its deliberations to address global challenges effectively. They also mention that the G-7's current agenda lacks consistency and that the proposed reforms would help the G-7 become more action-oriented. The authors believe that even Donald Trump could be drawn to G-7 reform.

title: How Companies Are Bracing for Trump’s Immigration Crackdown
content: Sectors including construction, hospitality, health care and manufacturing are on high alert. Economists are worried about the labor market and growth.
resumen:
**Businesses in the immigration cross hairs**

President Trump’s crackdown on illegal immigration is rapidly moving beyond Los Angeles, threatening to destabilize companies across the country.

Economists are worried about the long-term growth risks.

Shanon Stevenson, a partner at the employment law firm Fisher Phillips who specializes in immigration, said she was swamped with calls from businesses across America who fear having to shut down some operations, and potentially losing business and customers.

Nerves are particularly high in sectors like construction, hospitality, health care and manufacturing.

The Associated General Contractors of America has been telling contractors to prepare for construction site visits from agents with Immigration and Customs Enforcement, according to Brian Turmail, a spokesman for the group.

Raids have occurred across the country:

Stephen Miller, a White House aide, directed ICE officials in late May to target day laborers who typically gather near Home Depot stores, and 7-Eleven convenience stores, The Wall Street Journal reported. Home Depot is telling store associates to report raids near its stores immediately, a spokeswoman for the retailer told DealBook.

Immigration officials targeted Ambiance Apparel, a clothing manufacturer in downtown Los Angeles. The company was not notified in advance and is “deeply concerned” for its employees, Benjamin Gluck, a lawyer for the company, told DealBook. The Los Angeles Times reported that raids in the city had also taken place at smaller stores, including a carwash and a doughnut shop.

Sweeps are accelerating beyond California, too. In Omaha, dozens of people were reportedly detained on Tuesday when officials showed up at a meat production plant.

Employers are preparing. That might mean conducting I-9 audits to assess their exposure to immigration enforcement actions. If agents do arrive, lawyers are telling companies to check whether they have a signed judicial warrant, make a list of everything officials take from the workplace and document who is detained or taken away.

There are broader implications for the U.S. economy. Even companies that haven’t been targeted by ICE may feel the fallout as more employees stop showing up to work out of fear of possible raids. But a decline in immigration to the U.S. overall will create a long-term drag on growth, economists at Nomura found.

David Seif, the chief economist for developed markets at Nomura, told DealBook, “The bigger factor by far is the decline in the number of people entering the U.S., not the increase in the number exiting.”

**A networking start-up bets on growth in the A.I. age**

Meter, a networking start-up, plans to announce on Thursday that it has raised $170 million at a valuation of more than $1 billion, Michael de la Merced is the first to report.

The round was led by the venture capital firm General Catalyst, and includes new and existing investors like Baillie Gifford, JPMorgan Chase, Microsoft, Sequoia Capital, Jeffrey Katzenberg’s WndrCo and the A.I. entrepreneur Lachy Groom.

Meter provides all-in-one networking packages for customers, including switches, access points and security nodes, as well as the software to run and maintain the equipment.

Anil Varanasi, Meter’s co-founder and C.E.O., compared the product to the Amazon Web Services cloud computing platform.

Ravi Gupta, a partner at Sequoia, compared the product to turning networking into a utility like electricity.

The new funds will help finance expansion beyond existing customers like warehouses, schools and the hedge fund Bridgewater Associates to data centers. It also plans to grow internationally.

Hemant Taneja, General Catalyst’s C.E.O. told DealBook, “Networking spend is expected to grow massively in the next few years because of A.I. needs, and yet current networks are one of the biggest blockers” to growing A.I. computing power.

Meter’s early backers include Sam Altman of OpenAI, the former Google Cloud C.E.O. Diane Greene and the LinkedIn co-founder and A.I. investor Reid Hoffman. Microsoft has also struck a partnership with Meter to bring its products to customers.

Cisco announced this week that it was introducing a new generation of switches to keep up with huge data flows from A.I. services.

**Could crypto prop up America’s finances?**

The GENIUS Act passed a significant Senate procedural hurdle on Wednesday, moving one step closer to expansive new regulations of so-called stablecoins.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent testified on Capitol Hill on Wednesday that stablecoins could grow into a greater than $2 trillion market in the coming years.

Senator Bill Hagerty, Republican of Tennessee and a sponsor of the GENIUS Act, argued that the legislation was essential to fortifying America’s finances, in part by bolstering demand for Treasuries.

Mark Cabana, the head of U.S. rates strategy at Bank of America, wrote in the report, “We think stablecoins have the potential to disrupt traditional commercial banking models.”

title: House Bill’s Deduction for Car Loan Interest Would Not Offset Tariff-Related Auto Price Increases for Most Buyers
content: The auto loan interest deduction that recently passed the House is designed, at least in part, to mitigate the impact of tariff-induced price increases on vehicles assembled in America. But the ...
resumen: This analysis examines the extent to which a temporary income tax deduction for vehicle loan interest that recently passed the U.S. House of Representatives would be able to offset higher vehicle prices caused by recent increases in U.S. tariffs. Many buyers would be ineligible for the deduction. The lowest and highest income families would typically be ineligible for the auto loan interest deduction and thus would face the full tariff price effect without any offsetting deduction. Car buyers purchasing vehicles for which final assembly took place outside of America would also be ineligible. Industry experts estimate that 80 percent of cars priced under $30,000 are imported and thus buyers of those lower-priced cars would be barred from accessing the deduction. The loan interest deduction is incapable of offsetting even a modest 3 percent increase in the price of vehicles assembled in America. The deduction would offset only 36 to 43 percent of tariff-induced price increases for working-class families while buyers with higher incomes could see offsets ranging up to 85 percent. On a $40,000 vehicle, the net price increase would range from $201 to $879 for eligible claimants and would be $1,363 for car buyers ineligible for the deduction. If prices for vehicles assembled in the U.S. rise by 5 percent, as some industry analysts expect, families who are eligible for the loan interest deduction should generally expect to see less than half of the tariff expense offset by the tax deduction. The deduction would offset 22 to 26 percent of the price increase for working-class families while buyers with higher incomes could see offsets ranging up to 52 percent. On a $40,000 vehicle, the net price increase considering the tariffs and the deduction would range from $1,087 to $1,778 for eligible claimants, with the higher end of that increase falling on car buyers with more modest incomes. Car buyers who are ineligible for the deduction would face a $2,272 price increase. If prices rise by 10 percent because of the tariffs, families across the board should generally expect to see no more than a quarter of that added expense offset by the loan interest deduction. The deduction would offset 11 to 14 percent of the price increase for working-class families while buyers with higher incomes could see offsets ranging up to 27 percent. On a $40,000 vehicle, the net price increase would range from $3,303 to $4,026 for eligible claimants and would be $4,543 for car buyers ineligible for the deduction. The tax and spending bill that passed the U.S. House of Representatives last month would create a new tax deduction for car loan interest, modeled after a proposal made by then-candidate Donald Trump in the waning days of the 2024 presidential campaign. Specifically, the House bill would allow tax filers to deduct up to $10,000 per year of vehicle loan interest from their incomes for tax years 2025 through 2028, so long as final assembly of the vehicle took place in the U.S. In April, the Trump administration imposed 25 percent tariffs on all automobiles and most automobile parts imported into the U.S. that aren’t covered by the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). In weeks since, an executive order offered a two-year, partial credit against tariffs owed on parts for U.S.-assembled cars. The credit ranges up to 3.75 percent of the manufacturer’s suggested retail price for the first year and 2.5 percent for the second year. The tax deduction was envisioned partly as a way to offset some of the price increases on vehicles caused by tariffs. But the deduction would fail to offset even minor cost increases arising from automobile tariffs and would offer little or no benefit to low-income and working-class Americans. Economists at Anderson Consulting Group estimate that, even with the credit, the price of American assembled vehicles will rise by at least $2,000 because of the tariffs, with some models seeing higher increases of $10,000. Cox Automotive estimates at least a 5 percent price increase in the total cost of vehicles assembled in the U.S. With these figures in mind, we use a 5 percent price increase as our central case in this brief, with 3 and 10 percent increases presented to gain a sense of the impact of smaller, or larger, potential price increases. In practice, price changes will vary across vehicle types depending on the extent to which they contain foreign parts and the ways in which consumer demand is reshaped by the tariff regime more generally. The auto loan interest deduction in the House tax bill is being touted as a policy to promote purchases of American made vehicles. Generally, the value of the deduction would be the taxpayer’s top marginal tax rate multiplied by the interest they paid on the loan they used to purchase a U.S.-assembled vehicle. Single filers with adjusted gross income up to $100,000 and joint filers with income up to $200,000 could deduct up to $10,000 in vehicle loan interest per year. Those at the upper end of that range would be the top beneficiaries. The cap then phases down to zero for single filers with income over $150,000 and joint filers with income over $250,000. Because of these income limits, the taxpayers who would benefit are generally paying a top marginal tax rate of 10, 12, 22, or 24 percent. Figure 1 shows the extent to which typical car buyers should expect the loan interest deduction to offset the higher prices resulting from the tariffs. We find that buyers facing even small price increases for American assembled vehicles would not be made whole by the vehicle loan interest deduction. For instance, if the price of an American assembled vehicle rises by 5 percent, the deduction will cancel out roughly a quarter or less of the cost of the tariff for single filers earning $63,475 or less and joint filers earning $126,950 or less. At all eligible income levels, the deduction would fail to offset even a 3 percent price increase due to tariffs, which is on the low end of economists’ expectations. Working class families, who are expected to be most impacted by tariff-induced price increases, see little benefit from the auto loan deduction. The standard deduction excludes the first $15,000 of a single filer’s income from taxation in 2025, and the income tax rate is only 10 percent for the next $11,925 of income and 12 percent on the next $36,550 of income. This means the value of the deduction is between zero and 12 cents for each dollar spent on auto loan interest for single filers with income at or below $63,475. This is also the case for married filers with income up to $126,950. For an eligible $20,000 vehicle,

title: Trump anuncia aranceles del 55 % a China en nuevo acuerdo comercial
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunció este martes la imposición de aranceles del 55 % a productos importados desde China, como parte de un nuevo acuerdo comercial bilateral aún ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunció la imposición de aranceles del 55 % a productos importados desde China, como parte de un nuevo acuerdo comercial bilateral aún pendiente de aprobación. China mantendría un arancel del 10 % sobre productos estadounidenses.
El anuncio marca un endurecimiento en la política comercial de Washington hacia Pekín, elevando los gravámenes vigentes y tensando las relaciones económicas entre las dos principales economías del mundo.
No se ha difundido el contenido oficial del acuerdo, ni detalles sobre los sectores afectados ni los plazos de implementación.
Este tipo de medidas podría afectar a sectores clave como la tecnología, la automoción, la electrónica, los bienes de consumo y la agroindustria, tanto en China como en EE.UU., con efectos secundarios en mercados emergentes, incluida América Latina.
Un aumento arancelario de esta magnitud podría generar: alza de precios en productos importados en EE.UU., con impacto en la inflación doméstica; reducción de exportaciones chinas a su principal mercado global, con posibles ajustes internos en el gigante asiático; reconfiguración de cadenas de suministro globales, beneficiando a países terceros.
Para América Latina, esta nueva confrontación comercial puede tener efectos mixtos. Algunos países podrían beneficiarse como proveedores alternativos, especialmente México, Brasil, Argentina, Colombia y Perú. La inestabilidad en el comercio global y la volatilidad financiera asociada a las tensiones sino-estadounidenses podrían golpear el crecimiento regional y frenar inversiones.
El anuncio de Trump podría redibujar el mapa del comercio internacional, a solo meses de las elecciones presidenciales en EE.UU.

UU. del 10 de junio extiende un fallo similar emitido después de que el Tribunal del Comercio Internacional anulara los aranceles el 28 de mayo, argumentando que Trump se había excedido en su autoridad. En febrero, Trump firmó una orden ejecutiva que impone tarifas arancelarias a productos importados. El primer roce de esta batalla comercial se dio con México, Canadá y China. En abril, el presidente Trump publicó la lista de países con diferentes tipos de tasas arancelarias según el caso particular de cada socio comercial. En la lista, Guatemala fue incluida con un arancel recíproco del 10%. El gobierno de Bernardo Arévalo envió una delegación a Estados Unidos para negociar la reducción o eliminación de los referidos aranceles.

title: Aranceles de Trump golpean confianza del consumidor en Costa Rica
content: La guerra comercial impulsada a nivel global por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, que contempla un arancel general del 10% para las importaciones provenientes de Costa Rica, golpea la co ...
resumen:
La guerra comercial impulsada por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, que contempla un arancel general del 10% para las importaciones provenientes de Costa Rica, ya muestra efectos en las expectativas de los consumidores en el país.

En mayo del 2025, el Índice de Confianza del Consumidor (ICC), elaborado por la Escuela de Estadística de la Universidad de Costa Rica (UCR), registró un nivel de 52,3 puntos porcentuales (p. p.), lo que representa una caída de 0,9 puntos en comparación con el trimestre anterior, correspondiente a febrero.

El Índice de Expectativas Económicas (IEE), uno de los dos componentes del ICC, reflejó una disminución en el porcentaje de personas que prevén un mejor desempeño empresarial en los próximos 12 meses, al caer cuatro puntos porcentuales (p.p.), respecto a febrero pasado, y ubicarse en 30,3%.

Se registró un aumento inusitado en los últimos dos años en la proporción de encuestados que expresaron incertidumbre sobre el futuro de las empresas. En mayo, un 11,3% de las personas indicó no saber qué podría suceder con las compañías del sector productivo, lo que representa un incremento de 6,6 puntos porcentuales en comparación con febrero del 2025.

Fernanda Alvarado Leitón, coordinadora de la encuesta, atribuyó este panorama a las crecientes tensiones comerciales generadas por la imposición masiva de aranceles a nivel global.

Un nivel de incertidumbre como el actual no se observaba desde mayo del 2022, cuando el porcentaje alcanzó un 12,4%.

Se observó un incremento en el porcentaje de consumidores que prevé que el país atravesará “ni buenos ni malos tiempos” en los próximos cinco años. Esta categoría alcanzó un 16,2%, lo que representa un aumento de 4,1 puntos porcentuales con respecto a la medición anterior.

Se mantiene estable el porcentaje de personas que anticipa una mejor situación económica personal dentro de un año, con un 42,6%.

El economista Daniel Ortiz explicó a La Nación que los períodos marcados por incertidumbre comercial, como una guerra arancelaria, inciden directamente en la toma de decisiones de los consumidores.

El ICC se calcula mediante la Encuesta Nacional del Consumidor, que emplea una muestra probabilística de 707 personas mayores de 18 años con acceso a teléfono celular, lo que abarca el 97% de la población y tiene un nivel de confianza del 95%.

El Índice de Expectativas Económicas, uno de los dos componentes del Índice de Confianza del Consumidor en Costa Rica, reportó un aumento sin precedentes en la incertidumbre sobre el futuro de las empresas.

En relación con el Índice de Condiciones Económicas Actuales (ICEA), el segundo componente del ICC, el estudio trimestral más reciente reveló que la percepción sobre la situación económica personal se mantiene sin cambios significativos.

Un 31,5% de los consultados indicó estar mejor, un 47,8% manifestó sentirse igual y un 20,1% señaló estar en una condición desfavorable.

Fernanda Alvarado señaló que las expectativas futuras de los consumidores se están aproximando a los niveles de percepción sobre las condiciones actuales.

La política económica y social de la Administración de Rodrigo Chaves Robles acumula dos años con una percepción mayoritariamente negativa entre la población.

Desde mayo del 2023, los resultados del ICC muestran un balance negativo en la percepción ciudadana sobre la política económica del gobierno en temas como inflación, pobreza y desempleo.

Un 34,4% de los consultados calificó como “pobre” la labor de la Administración Chaves Robles en materia de política económica (–8,6 p. p.), mientras que un 26,7% la consideró “buena” y otro 34,4% opinó que el gobierno está haciendo “lo necesario” (+6,5 p. p.).

En mayo, el porcentaje de consumidores que anticipa un aumento en los niveles de pobreza durante los próximos 12 meses disminuyó a 34,8%, lo que representa una caída de 6,5 puntos porcentuales.

Creció en una magnitud similar el grupo que prevé que la situación se mantendrá sin cambios, alcanzando un 47,1% (+6,0 p. p.).

Un 33,0% de los encuestados espera un incremento en el desempleo, un 23,4% anticipa una reducción y un 40,1% considera que la tasa se mantendrá igual.

title: Trump strikes massive China deal that changes everything
content: Trump announces major China trade deal securing rare earth minerals with 55% US tariffs vs 10% China tariffs. Agreement reshapes global supply chains.
resumen:
President Trump announced Wednesday that he’s secured a deal with China that could fundamentally reshape the global economy, giving America access to critical rare earth minerals while imposing a tariff structure that heavily favors the United States.

This deal strikes at the heart of China’s strategic dominance in the materials that power everything from electric vehicles to military defense systems.

The timing couldn’t be more crucial, as the world transitions toward renewable energy sources that depend heavily on rare earth minerals.

China produces roughly 60% of the world’s rare earth minerals and processes nearly 90% of global supply.

According to his Truth Social post, America will receive 55% tariffs while China gets only 10%.

The concessions that America is apparently making in this deal center around allowing Chinese students to attend U.S. colleges and universities.

Brent crude futures rose $1 per barrel to $67.87, while West Texas Intermediate futures climbed 1.8% to $66.14.

For years, U.S. officials have warned about the national security risks of depending on China for critical materials needed for defense systems and emerging technologies.

If this agreement holds and gets implemented as described, it could represent a fundamental shift in how global supply chains operate and how countries approach strategic resource management.

Industries ranging from automotive to defense to renewable energy could benefit significantly.

Vera Emoghene is the author.

title: FMI alerta sobre leyes del Congreso que golpean finanzas tras polémico fallo del TC que dio carta libre al gasto futuro
content: El Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) advirtió que el Congreso ha aprobado más de 160 iniciativas con impacto fiscal, muchas sin sustento técnico, y que en conjunto comprometen recursos equivalentes ...
resumen: El Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI) advirtió que el Congreso ha aprobado más de 160 iniciativas con impacto fiscal, muchas sin sustento técnico, y que en conjunto comprometen recursos equivalentes al 5,7% del PBI. El FMI recuerda la sentencia del Tribunal Constitucional que permitió al Parlamento legislar en materia de gasto futuro, debilitando los candados fiscales. En solo una década, entre 2014 y 2024, el número de proyectos de ley tributarios aumentó en un 190%. Según el Consejo Fiscal, desde el 2021, el Congreso actual ha aprobado 168 iniciativas con impacto fiscal. El proyecto de la nueva ley agraria conocida como la Ley Chlimper 2.0 — recorta impuestos del 29,5% al 15% a las agroexportadoras — impactará en 0,2 del producto bruto interno (PBI) anuales, lo que representa aproximadamente S/1.800 millones. La iniciativa de la condonación de multas, recargos e intereses del programa Reactiva Perú, tendrá un impacto de 8% del PBI, mientras que la condonación de deudas tributarias será de 7% del PBI, ambas se encuentran en Comisión del Congreso. La proporción de medidas aprobadas por insistencia, es decir, con opinión negativa del Ministerio de Economía, aumentó al 20% en esta legislatura, comparado con solo 9% en los 20 años anteriores. Otras iniciativas incluyen la extensión de una tasa reducida del Impuesto General a las Ventas (IGV) para micro y pequeñas empresas del sector turismo; un nuevo marco general para zonas económicas especiales con tasas reducidas del impuesto a la renta (IR) durante 25 años y la condonación de multas e intereses para los participantes en programas de amnistía tributaria. El FMI recomienda que todas las iniciativas legislativas deben ser acompañadas de un informe técnico del Ministerio de Finanzas (MEF) "con un cálculo riguroso". El FMI recordó en su reporte acerca del controvertido fallo del Tribunal Constitucional emitido en 2022, en el que le otorgó al Congreso iniciativa de gasto. El FMI señala que esta interpretación tuvo implicancias inmediatas e importantes, ya que incentivó a los legisladores a involucrarse más activamente en la política fiscal. Otras medidas que incrementan el gasto incluyen son la expansión de la masa salarial a través del nombramiento de trabajadores temporales como empleados permanentes, aumentos salariales y nuevas contrataciones, la creación de 20 nuevas universidades, la introducción de un Congreso Bicameral y la reforma del sistema de pensiones. El FMI sostiene que las tensiones preelectorales cada vez están aumentando. El FMI espera que el crecimiento económico del país para este año se modere al 2,8%. Respecto a los efectos iniciales de los aranceles de Donald Trump y la desaceleración del crecimiento mundial, señala que el impacto sería negativo, aunque relativamente moderado, mientras que espera que la inflación se mantenga dentro del rango meta del Banco Central de Reserva (BCR) situado entre el 1% y 3%.

title: Qué semanita para la Presidenta de México
content: Vaya semana que le ha tocado protagonizar a la presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, en la que parece que todo le sale mal y no se ve para cuándo pueda cambiarle la suerte, tristemente, en perjuici ...
resumen:
Vaya semana que le ha tocado protagonizar a la presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, en la que parece que todo le sale mal y no se ve para cuándo pueda cambiarle la suerte, tristemente, en perjuicio de los mexicanos.

Todo empezó con los resultados de las elecciones. La poca afluencia de personas que acudieron a votar por el nuevo Poder Judicial la obligaron a salir a presumir un "éxito" que nadie le creyó, ni siquiera los simpatizantes de la 4T, quienes ya no saben cómo justificar un triste 13% de participación ciudadana.

Además, también tuvo que tratar de responder por el pésimo papel que hizo Andy López Beltrán, quien entregó malas cuentas en Veracruz y Durango.

Después, las ocurrencias de Donald Trump le recordaron de golpe que el tema de los aranceles no está resuelto, porque siguen tratando a México dependiendo del humor del Presidente de EUA, sumado a los estragos millonarios que está ocasionando el cierre de la frontera al ganado de exportación y los nuevos impuestos al envío de remesas.

Luego, el llamado a los connacionales a movilizarse ante las redadas contra los inmigrantes en Estados Unidos fue una bomba de tiempo que acabó por explotarle ayer, cuando la secretaria de Seguridad Nacional de Estados Unidos, Kristi Noem, la acusó directamente de incitar a las violentas protestas que sacudieron a Los Ángeles, California.

Y por si fuera poco, un hecho donde México violó la soberanía de Guatemala, tras un enfrentamiento armado entre fuerzas de seguridad de Chiapas y un grupo criminal en el vecino país del sur, comprobado con videos que circulan en redes sociales.

Y ya no hablamos de algunas notas que seguramente le han de haber provocado fuertes dolores de cabeza, como la pérdida de miles de empleos en mayo, el costo real de lo que al Gobierno Federal le cuesta subsidiar el capricho del Tren Maya, las inundaciones en la CDMX en las que la oposición también la responsabiliza por haber heredado ese problema, los pleitos entre morenistas en Guerrero.

Si le está yendo tan mal a la Presidenta, la afectación para el país será en ese nivel.

Claudia luce cada vez más sola, remando contra corriente a los grupos dentro de Morena que no la respetan y contra una oposición sedienta de venganza.

Sheinbaum parece traer una muy mala racha de situaciones que, de no resolverlas, empezarían a afectar a millones de mexicanos y, por supuesto, a debilitar seriamente su proyecto de Gobierno.

title: U.S. Inflation Remains Muted, With Limited Effects From Tariffs
content: The Consumer Price Index rose 2.4 percent in May, from a year ago, a reading that reflects only the initial impact of President Trump’s tariffs.
resumen:
Businesses across the United States have for months warned that they would raise prices on their customers in response to President Trump’s tariffs.

The Consumer Price Index, released on Wednesday, rose 2.4 percent in May from a year earlier, just above April’s 2.3 percent annual increase.

“Core” inflation steadied at 2.8 percent.

On a monthly basis, the overall measure rose 0.1 percent, in line with the core index. Both were below economists’ expectations.

The latest data, released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, reflects a mixed picture about the economic impact of Mr. Trump’s tariffs.

Most of the businesses surveyed in May by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said they had passed on at least some of the tariffs to their customers. Nearly half of the service-oriented companies passed along all of those higher costs by raising their prices, whereas one-third of manufacturers responding to the survey did the same.

The latest Beige Book, which compiles economic anecdotes from the 12 regional banks across the Federal Reserve System, noted that there were “widespread reports of contacts expecting costs and prices to rise at a faster rate going forward.” Those that expected to pass along higher costs planned to do so “within three months,” the report said.

In categories expected to be most exposed to tariffs, like furniture, prices were down 0.8 percent in May. Clothing costs fell 0.4 percent, while prices for both new and used cars also declined.

Samuel Tombs, chief U.S. economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, described the tariff impact in May’s report as “microscopic.”

David Kelly, chief global strategist at JPMorgan Asset Management, said that if the current tariffs stayed in place, price pressures would start to build up late this summer and peak in the fourth quarter of the year, pushing inflation to an annual rate of around 4 percent.

In minutes from the Fed’s last meeting in May, the central bank’s staff penciled in a forecast that carried the whiff of stagflation. It said a recession was “almost as likely” as its forecast for subdued growth and higher unemployment. Tariffs, it said, were expected to boost inflation “markedly this year” and continue to add price pressures in 2026 before inflation trended back to the 2 percent target by 2027.

Mr. Trump said on Wednesday that a fresh deal with Beijing was “done,” but the full details had not yet been released.

In response to the latest inflation data, Mr. Trump reiterated his call for the Fed to lower interest rates by a full percentage point.

After lowering borrowing costs by a percentage point last year, the central bank has kept interest rates steady since January, at a range of 4.25 percent to 4.5 percent.

The 10-year Treasury yield dropped almost 0.1 percentage points, a large move in that market, to just above 4.4 percent.

title: The Fed Is Bracing for Tariffs to Show Up in the Inflation Data
content: While President Trump has pointed to cooling prices as a reason for rate cuts, the Federal Reserve has kept rates unchanged to guard against tariff-fueled disruptions that could derail a soft landing, ...
resumen:
Inflation has cooled every month in 2025 so far but that streak could end today, according to both consensus estimates and alternative indicators.

The May CPI report, due at 8:30 AM ET, is expected to hit 2.5 percent year-over-year, according to FactSet. That would be higher than the 2.3 percent seen in April, and it would mark the first increase from the prior month since January.

While President Trump has pointed to cooling prices as a reason for rate cuts, the Federal Reserve has kept rates unchanged to guard against tariff-fueled disruptions that could derail a soft landing, though they have yet to show up in the inflation data.

Truflation, a real-time inflation tracker, showed annual inflation at 1.60 percent in early May. This week, it reached 1.93 percent — still modest but trending higher. It’s also a notable step up from the 1.22 percent seen the week of Liberation Day.

The Fed has held rates steady all year in part to insulate against a trade war. But tariffs aren’t the only inflationary pressure at play.

Last month, the White House abandoned its fiscal restraint and pivoted to big spending, swapping its cost-cutting agenda to run the economy hot. That shift, which sparked the public fallout between Elon Musk and President Trump, could feed price growth in the coming months.

The latest New York Fed survey, as Opening Bell Daily reported Monday, shows consumers’ 12-month inflation expectations dropped from 3.6 percent in April to 3.2 percent in May.

Meanwhile, the majority of C-suite executives expect improving business conditions and robust consumer demand for products this year, according to the latest CEO Confidence Index.

If May CPI comes in hot, as economists predict, the Fed’s wait-and-see stance will look prescient. But if it surprises cooler once again, it will force everyone to ask a narrative-breaking question: Are tariffs really the biggest inflation threat?

title: Peso appreciates to strongest exchange rate in 10 months
content: The appreciation on Wednesday came after the peso closed at 19.06 to the dollar on Tuesday, according to the Bank of Mexico.
resumen: The Mexican peso appreciated to its strongest position against the US dollar in almost a year on Wednesday, dipping below 19 to the greenback. At 2 p.m. Mexico City time, the peso was trading at 18.92 to the dollar, according to Yahoo Finance!. The peso was even stronger earlier in the day, reaching 18.82 to the dollar. The last time the peso was stronger was in August last year. The appreciation on Wednesday came after the peso closed at 19.06 to the dollar on Tuesday, according to the Bank of Mexico. Gabriela Siller, director of economic analysis at Mexican bank Banco Base, said on social media site X that the peso appreciated on Wednesday due to three reasons: The expectation that the United States Federal Reserve will cut its interest rate while the Bank of Mexico “could pause” its easing cycle; Optimism due to the trade agreement between the United States and China; Speculation that United States President Donald Trump could remove the 50% tariff on steel and aluminum from Mexico. Reuters reported on Tuesday that “the United States and Mexico are negotiating a deal to reduce or eliminate President Donald Trump’s 50% steel tariffs on imports up to a certain volume.”. Bloomberg reported earlier on Tuesday that the two countries were “closing in on a deal” that would remove Trump’s tariffs on Mexican steel “up to a certain volume.”. The United States imposed a 25% tariff on all steel and aluminum imports in March, and Trump doubled the duty to 50% last week. On Wednesday, the U.S. president announced that the United States’ “deal with China is done, subject to final approval with President Xi and me.”. Trump said that the U.S. is “getting a total of 55% tariffs,” while “China is getting 10%.”. Mexican financial group Monex said that the peso got a boost from “the optimism of investors, who anticipate a possible trade agreement [on steel tariffs] between Mexico and the United States.”. In another X post on Tuesday, Siller said that data showing that annual inflation in the United States was 2.4% in May increased the probability that the U.S. Federal Reserve would cut the federal funds rate. At 4.42% in May, inflation in Mexico was considerably higher than the rate in the United States. The Bank of Mexico’s key interest rate is currently set at 8.50%, while the Fed’s rate is much lower at a 4.25%-4.5% range. Siller said that the peso could appreciate to 18.50 to the US dollar this year “if there isn’t aversion to global risk, if Trump removes tariffs on Mexico and if the Fed cuts its [interest] rate while the Bank of Mexico pauses its cycle of interest rate cuts.”. The bank Banamex said on Tuesday that it estimates a USD:MXN exchange rate of 20.6 in December, which would represent a depreciation of more than 8% for the peso compared to its current position. Banamex predicted that “noise that could arise” from the start of the USMCA review — which is scheduled for 2026 but could commence this year — will cause the peso to depreciate later in 2025.
